name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission by Irene Tinagli, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the Institutions and bodies of economic and monetary union: preventing conflicts of interest related to employment former officials of public institutions (O-000048/2019 - B9-0001/2020) (2019/2959(RSP)).

name: Irene TINAGLI
text: author. – Madam President, on 17 September 2019, Mr Adam Farkas announced his resignation from his position as Executive Director of the European Banking Authority (EBA), which will be effective on 31 January 2020 to become, starting on 1 February 2020, the CEO of the Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME), a well-known lobbying company that, according to its website, is the voice of Europe’s wholesale financial services. Let me remind you what the EBA’s responsibilities are: the EBA is responsible for supervising the EU’s banking sector and for setting technical standards implementing key financial regulations. This makes the EBA a fundamental institution that regulates and supervises the financial sector. It also, of course, makes it a constant lobbying target for the industry. AFME, like other stakeholders, appears to have permanent interactions with the EBA. In compliance with the staff regulations and ethical rules, the EBA’s Board of Supervisors has taken a decision to impose fairly light restrictions on its Executive Director, both while in service at the EBA and after leaving the EBA. However, the restrictions on Mr Farkas’s future employment do not seem either realistic or enforceable. Unless Mr Farkas simply becomes AFME’s poster boy, I cannot really find a single topic that AFME covers that does not fall within the remit of the EBA and does not relate to the work of Mr Farkas. Moreover, it is not clear to me who will monitor the effective application of these restrictions, in particular the one that provides that he cannot engage in lobbying or advocacy of the EBA or have professional contacts with EBA staff for 24 months after leaving the Authority. How are we going to enforce that or control that? Who’s going to do that? So, for this reason, we call for a review of this decision by the EBA Board of Supervisors. Sadly, Mr Farkas’ is not the first case, and will probably not be the last, of a post—public employment job in the private sector that poses evident problems of conflicts of interest, but we absolutely must act to ensure that this is the last. I really hope that this is the last.  Revolving doors, where one jumps from public institutions to top positions in the private sector, from regulators to regulated, or from supervisors to supervised, and vice versa unfortunately not only undermine the credibility of the individual engaging in such behaviour, but undermine the credibility of the whole institution and, more generally, the trust that citizens have in public bodies, and the trust that citizens have in public institutions is the backbone of democracies. So we shall not tolerate our European institutions and agencies’ credibility crumbling just because of some individuals’ interest, and we should always remain vigilant in making sure and guaranteeing that they are not influenced by private interest. For this reason, we call on the Commission to assess the current practice on post—public employment at European and national level, to extend this review to pre-public employment conflicts of interest, and also to put in place a harmonised legal framework, which should include an extension of the possibility to block professional moves and the provision of a cooling—off period that is proportionate to the specific case and accompanied by an appropriate temporary allowance. Finally, we call on the Commission also to assess whether it is appropriate that the EU agencies concerned decide for themselves on the enforcement of the rules for the prevention of conflicts of interest and how a consistent application of the rules can be ensured.  I was glad to see that the resolution was supported unanimously by Members in the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) with no votes against and no abstentions. I hope this is a clear signal and that the plenary widely supports the resolution as well.

name: Janez Lenarčič
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, from the outset, let me underline that I fully share with you the consideration of the importance of high ethical standards in the European civil service in general. These high ethical standards are vital – vital components that allow democracy to thrive. The effective operation of ethics in the civil service requires that public officials and agents be independent, impartial and responsible to the people. I understand that the move of Mr Farkas from the European Banking Authority (EBA) to the private sector generated some concerns and in this context, you addressed questions to the Commission with regards to its policy and its legal framework. You have also raised the point in relation to the horizontal harmonisation of the ethical legal framework across the EU institutions.  The Staff Regulations and the implementing rules adopted by the Commission apply to all EU agencies, unless agencies adopt their own implementing rules which are validated by the Commission. At the same time, each agency holds its independence, since they are separate legal entities. This means that agencies are independently responsible for the implementation of the rules, compliance and for adopting individual decisions concerning their staff and this also concerns Mr Farkas.  The decision concerning Mr Farkas was taken by the EBA Board of Supervisors, which is the decision-making body to decide on and enforce post-employment restrictions. The members of the board with voting rights are the heads of the national public authorities, competent for the supervision of credit institutions in each Member State. The Commission participates in the board meetings with only one representative, without voting rights. This mode of governance is the choice of the legislator.  As mentioned, the EBA, like all EU institutions, is bound by the Staff Regulations. These contain a comprehensive ethical framework. The latest Staff Regulations – reform of 2013 – reinforced this framework in the area of post-employment restrictions. More specifically, the Staff Regulations require that potential conflicts of interest are assessed upon recruitment or integration after a period of leave on personal grounds. These provisions explicitly address the issue of lobbying in a democracy during leave on personal grounds or after having left the institution. With particular regard to post-employment activities, the assessment is made on a case-by-case basis. Prohibitions or restrictions must be well reasoned and proportionate. For each case there must be appropriate balance between the need to ensure the integrity of the work of the institution, through temporary prohibitions and restrictions and, on the other hand, the need to respect the former staff members’ right to engage in work and to pursue a freely chosen or accepted occupation, as enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  On these matters, the Commission has in place implementing rules which are regularly revised to reflect recommendations, in particular from the European Parliament, the European Ombudsman and the European Court of Auditors. This was the case when the new decision on outside activities and assignments and occupational activities after leaving the service was adopted in 2018.  I would also like to underline the importance of transparency. Since 2014, the Staff Regulations provide that each institution must publish annually information on the implementation of the prohibition for former senior managers for one year to engage in lobbying or advocacy vis-à-vis staff of the former institution on matters for which they were responsible during the last three years in service. The Commission has just published its fifth report. This is part of the Commission’s overall efforts to achieve greater transparency, which also includes publication of Commissioners’ and senior staff meetings and updates to the EU transparency register, to name just a few.  Over the recent years, the Commission has indeed closely cooperated with the European Ombudsman in the framework of her inquiries looking into the revolving doors phenomenon. When closing its second inquiry in February last year, the European Ombudsman confirmed that the Commission has high standards in the area of ethics and transparency and encouraged the Commission to continue to lead by example. In July last year, the European Court of Auditors issued a report on the ethical framework of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission. The Court of Auditors’ audit confirmed that, to a large extent, the audited institutions have established adequate ethical frameworks and that the Commission is well advanced in this matter. The new College marks a new momentum to address ethical challenges, together with new ideas and determination. In this respect, Vice-President Jourová has been entrusted by the President to work with the European Parliament and the Council on setting up an independent ethics body common to all EU institutions. Cooperation with the other institutions in this process, of course, is key to making this a success.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. Latent conflicts of interest, such as those that can arise from a direct change of top staff from supervisory authorities to the private sector, erode confidence in the European Union and its institutions. The truth, however – and this has already been mentioned – is that we cannot, of course, impose bans on professions. Therefore, if we want to oblige top officials to take a cooling-off period, we must, of course, also grant appropriate compensation. Otherwise, we are really going into legally difficult territory. In this respect, it is necessary for the European Commission not only to say 'this is an agency that has its own rules', but for us to think together about a single legal framework. I very much regret that the Council is not taking part in this debate, because the single legal framework also requires the support of the Council. It would be nice if the Presidency would also take this issue with us to deal with it. It is therefore also part of giving the supervisory authorities themselves less leeway. After all, it is not acceptable for them to decide for themselves what is permissible and what is not allowed, because they measure according to different criteria than should be the case for top European officials. However, ladies and gentlemen, we must of course also be a little careful. I always say: if you want to ride out, you have to keep your own stable clean. And that is why it is also part of this – and we as the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats have included this in the resolution – that we see this not only for institutions, but also for Parliament: when a Green employee, who has been working in a month to regulate investment funds and investment firms, suddenly moves to the umbrella organisation of the British asset management industry next month, and of course without a cooling-off period. , then this is also a questionable process. That is why I say very clearly: I am glad that in our resolution we have clearly stated that the provisions in the Staff Regulations should also apply to employees with regard to conflicts of interest.

name: Paul TANG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, today it feels especially good to be a Member of this Parliament. While the Guardian of the Treaties has looked the other way thus far, Commissioner, this institution has taken up the challenge to defend the rules that we hold dear. The EU has strong safeguards against revolving doors and the perverse incentives that come from that. These new rules enable us to prevent employees from taking up positions that harm our collective interest. However, without their application and enforcement, rules turn into paper tigers. It is this vital that this Parliament reminds the Commission, reminds the European Banking Authority (EBA), reminds the public that we will not let vital rules descend into irrelevance. With this resolution, we send the reminder loud and clear: we demand that Mr Farkas’ move be blocked. If this demand is not met, we will stand ready to ban him from this Parliament.  But it doesn’t end here. We see a sort of intimate love story developing between the EBA on the one hand, and Association for Financial Markets in Europe (AFME) on the other hand now that Gerry Cross has also been appointed. We need to continue to address potential conflicts of interest in the EU, and this starts in two weeks’ time if Mr Farkas indeed takes up his new job. I trust that the parliamentary leadership will implement our call not to grant Mr Farkas an access badge. Commissioner, we will be monitoring you and other agendas from your colleagues to verify whether you heed our advice not to meet Mr Farkas in the coming two years. Well, I’m proud of the strong stance that we have taken together. We should highlight one thing: no one comes out of this story looking good. So, much better than standing up in defence of our common rules is not to let their strength be doubted at all.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, during the financial crisis, we learned that the excessive closeness between the regulators and the regulated – the banks, the financial sector – can have a real cost to taxpayers. We’re not talking about vague ethical standards without implications, we’re talking about rules that actually matter to the taxpayers. Why? Because if those who are setting the rules are actually not setting the rules for the taxpayers, but they are setting the rules for the system, because they’re hoping to go back to the financial system, etc., what we end up is with rules that are actually not working, with rules that lead to bailouts and with rules that lead to taxpayers footing the bill. The favourite bet of investors is one where heads they win, tails the taxpayers lose. That’s why this case is so important, and that’s why Parliament is sending a very loud and clear message.  I congratulate my colleagues from all the four main parties – Mr Tang, Ms Tingali, Chair of the Committee, Mr Ferber, Mr Giegold – on coming together and passing already a resolution on this case unanimously, the entire Parliament. We are continuing working on building and maintaining these boundaries between regulators and those who are regulated. This case goes beyond any conception of those boundaries. It basically makes a laughing stock of those Staff Regulations you mentioned, Mr Commissioner, and it basically means, well you know, if you want to ignore those rules and go around them, then you may. That’s why Parliament has taken such a decisive action. We don’t take this this problem lightly. We will be policing and monitoring in the future that the Staff Regulations are maintained and enforced. That ethical body you proposed, Mr Commissioner, seems like a good idea. Anything that can make this work, this prohibition and these boundaries between the two sides of the wall work, and we think that that’s to the benefit of our economies, our citizens our taxpayers.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The case of Mr Farkas has rightly caused a great deal of attention, because this is an important conflict of interest. When the european banking authority's number two moves directly from this position to the top of the big banking lobby, it weakens citizens' confidence in European democracy. And the further European institutions move away from local democracy, the higher the ethical standards must be. That is why it is also true that the EU has had ever higher standards in areas such as transparency of lobbying and documents. Unfortunately, however, in the area of revolving doors between the private sector and powerful lobbies and public positions, the rules are not so strong. That is why we need stricter rules here. The rules so far are a bad joke. This also applies to the rules that have now been imposed on Mr Farkas. It is important that the European Commission applies the Staff Regulations strictly, and we know that one reason why the Commission has not so thoroughly examined and rejected the Farkas case so far was also because one often does not look so closely at one's own staff. Yes, it is true that these problems also exist in the European Parliament. This starts with parliamentary assistants, but it does not stop at Members who continue to receive salaries after the end of the mandate, without any restrictions on conflicts of interest being attached to it. And that is why I am happy to take the initiative. Let us set ourselves rules here in this House. Because when we made our report on the integrity, transparency and accountability of the European Parliament, there was very, very little support for my proposals to limit the revolving door. That is why I am pleased that we are now regulating this differently here. In particular, however, the European Banking Authority must take seriously our call to reconsider this decision. If it does not do so, then there must be consequences. And we have an opportunity, because the new number two also comes from the big banking lobby, and we will see how seriously we actually mean this decision here. This is central, and the Sabathil case, which is currently widely reported, is also a cause for concern as to the revolving door effect. All the institutions must therefore clean up this and show the consequences of this resolution.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Much has already been said, but not yet by everyone, and I do not want to say so much, because the facts are on the table. The analysis is, I think, clear, and something needs to change here. In my view, however, it is not acceptable for the authority concerned to define the rules with which such cases are to be resolved. These rules must be met by the relevant institutions here, namely the Council, Parliament and the Commission. We must pull together to prevent these problems from arising. At the end of the day, let us be honest, the fact is that even if we give ourselves a lot of rules here – it costs a lot of money on the one hand, as Mr Ferber said, it also costs us a lot, a lot of energy and time – if there is no sense among the people concerned that the whole thing has a 'taste', as we did in Baden-Württemberg. where I come from, say. Then we will not find any solutions here. Such stories, such changes from civil servants to the private sector, must be solved by the individuals themselves. We cannot watch such things spread here, no matter where you are, in Parliament or in these institutions. That is why I ask for more instinct, also for more personal concern, that such things no longer occur.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Madam President, we support the resolution which Parliament will vote on and which the ECON committee has brought to this debate. Unfortunately, it seems that what the European Commission has brought us was a disappointment. This is customary, and has been customary in successive European Commissions.  Following the 2008 financial crisis, the then President of the European Commission said that the influence of the financial industry on European policies with the influence of citizens had to be rebalanced. The President of the European Commission who made this fine statement was called Barroso and, as we all know, ended up at Goldman Sachs. And this problem, which is an endemic problem in multiple European institutions, becomes infinitely more serious every time we discuss the financial system and its regulators in European committees, in various regulators, in the European Parliament.  The decisions that have been taken by the European Banking Authority in the Farkas case are, as has already been said, a bad joke. The restrictions that are imposed from not contacting people working in the Authority, even if this restriction could be inclosed and cannot obviously prevent you from passing your phone book to your new colleagues. As is ridiculous and would be rife, if this were not such a serious matter, the restriction of not using the information it has accumulated in eight years in the European Banking Authority in its new functions, which are lobbying functions, in which the European Banking Authority is a central regulator. Mr. Farkas will be paid to use that information. The salary he will receive is the price of this information. And what the European Commission has told us here is that the principle of regulatorindependence basically means that the democratic institutions that European citizens have elected cannot do anything, which means that important regulators such as the European Banking Authority can be fully captured by the economic sectors they aim to regulate.  Moreover, it should be stressed that this decision we are discussing is taken by a President of the European Banking Authority who himself comes from a lobbying position at Santander, and therefore this story, this novel in the European Banking Authority, already has many episodes. And while this is a serious matter, I cannot help but smile when the right to work is invoked. What we are discussing is the right to move directly from a regulator to a lobbying position. The right to work? If European workers were protected as much by the European institutions as this man, who went from regulator to lobbyist, would be much better off.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the last financial crisis made a clear grey space, where the financial sector, the authorities, regulators, supervisors, shared information, shared spaces, shared debates. And they shared them in such a way that, somehow or another, they ended up influencing decisions. And this perception of European citizenship, this perception that public authorities are not how independent they should be of some kind of interest groups, is a perception that undermines trust in the democratic system, is an appreciation that undermines trust in Europe, in the Community project.  I think it is very important that, in this case we are discussing, Parliament's Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs unanimously approved — unanimity, not a broad majority, unanimity — a number of requirements, of recommendations to avoid such revolving doors. Because we believe it is unreasonable for colleagues in the supervisory institutions to be those who need to assess whether or not public employees of those agencies may or may not go to certain companies.  An independent agency, with competence for all European institutions, the Commission and the supervisory agencies, is needed, which somehow clearly assesses the criteria, finally assesses the characteristics of these labour movements, in order to improve the confidence of European citizens in the institutions, to improve confidence in European democracy and to open a space, as I say , greater political responsibility through the Union as a whole.

name: Damien CARÊME
text: Madam President, everyone says it, but we must do it: we must put an end to the opaque and disproportionate influence of lobbies on our public policies: the financial lobby, but also the nuclear or fossil fuel lobby, etc. They are numerous and organized to advance in the shadows their private interests, with the consequences that we know: banking disturbances, subsidies to energies of the past, and so on. More transparency is needed to combat these shadowy forces, because we are far from done with corruption; even in France today, as evidenced, for example, by the council of Europe's latest report of 9 January 2020, which points to the persistence of grey areas in the fight against corruption and calls for greater transparency in contacts between the executive and interest groups so that their influence on decisions is clearer. To regain the full confidence of citizens, what everyone is calling for here, it is time to put an end to the collusion between public and private interests. For example, because this is the one we are interested in today, a senior official, Mr Farkas, in charge of the European supervision of banks, should not be able to become director of the main financial lobby overnight. However, that is what is happening at the moment and it is not acceptable. Stricter rules are needed to preserve the integrity of our institutions. For example, longer transition periods between two activities and potential conflicts of interest with a ban on access badges to Parliament are needed. Above all, there needs to be truly independent supervision when such situations arise, thanks to the creation of this independent ethics authority that you mentioned in your remarks. When we say we want to defend the public interest, we must act accordingly, starting with accepting transparency and clarity.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, do not think that this morning we are gaining the virginity of the European Parliament and the European institutions by sounding the alarm, decades later, that conflicts of interest, the influence of lobbies, revolving doors and the absence of ethics exist within the European institutions. We have been denouncing this for years and the citizens are denouncing it: these buildings and institutions have been deaf for years about the fact that within these institutions, in the European institutions, in monetary union, there was a strong influence on lobbies. But it is also important to look at what has happened, where monetary union has created damage: there are shops that have closed, businesses that have closed, citizens who have lost jobs because of the influence of these lobbies. So let us not only regulate the future but seek responsibility for those actions and mistakes, but above all for the criminal premeditations that have taken place in recent years.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, in the eurozone regulation at European level is still developing, sometimes by trial and error. The role of the top managers is crucial in setting, interpreting and implementing regulatory texts. On that basis, new administrative structures and practice will eventually be developed, as the Banking Union and the Capital Markets Union beckon. Complex interests are at play – national and transnational, state and private. Subject to such complex pressures, those managing and arbitrating the euro’s regulatory movement must be totally neutral. All States and corporate actors, the general European public, the regulators themselves, must have the assurance that this is the case. That assurance is not available as of now.  Post-employment calculations and expectations can colour the way in which the regulatory process is being developed. Also, post-employment the inside information and know-how obtained when working in regulatory mode can serve to give advantages to one’s new employer, but the revolving door practice is still being tolerated. There is, too, a reverse revolving door issue. We need to understand how conflicts of interest could arise from positions held pre-public employment when nominating people to top regulatory or executive positions. That problem, too, cannot be ignored. We should not tolerate the contamination of the regulatory neutrality that the eurozone requires if it is to develop properly.

name: Mikuláš PEKSA
text: – Madam President, I am standing here today to denounce the problem of revolving doors between EU institutions and private lobby groups. Too often, senior EU officials leave their high level positions in order to exploit inside information and contacts to the benefit of private sector lobbying. Whilst senior EU officials already have the obligation to report on the new functions they intend to take, this is too often ignored. Post-public employment conflict of interest has really become a systemic problem that has the potential to endanger our integrity and reputation. EU institutions should be an example of high ethical and transparency standards. This is why I call on the Commission to do more to prevent such conflicts of interests and on the European Court of Auditors to look into this systemic issue and identify best practices.  Last October, the Commission promised to review the post-employment ethical regulations. And in order not just to criticise, but also to provide some solutions, I would like to ask for four things: first, a harmonised legal framework, which would apply the same ethical standards at EU and national level; second, establishment of an independent ethical body to investigate all problematic cases; third, a mandatory 12-months’ cooling-off period to forbid a former senior EU official to lobby his ex-colleagues. Finally, in order to ensure maximum transparency of our public institutions, declarations of interests and finding of conflicts of interests shall be published online to make it accessible to all citizens.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been a member of the European We are in a quandary here. On the one hand, all the concerns raised about the move from the European institutions to the private sector are justified, and they are right to annoy the public. On the other hand, however, we do not want there to be no way out of public office. Public offices are awarded on a temporary basis. We need to bring talented heads from the private sector to the institutions and, conversely, these minds need to know that it is not a trap for them, but that, once they have done their job, there is also the possibility of returning to other tasks.  In other words, problems are pre-programmed, and dealing with them cannot be in creating such over-regulation that these people will no longer come. Because that harms us because we need competence. In this respect, the solution is to strengthen personal concern by making cases of obvious abuse public. The corrective to political misconduct is a critical public, but not the hundredth or thousandth authority with regulations.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, we are coming back with this debate, because this is not the first time we have talked about conflict of interest and, above all, prevention of conflict of interest.  I want to refer to the last debate, on 24 October last year, when Commissioner Mimica was telling us here that yes, he recognises that we need to do a review, a review of the legal framework, harmonise it, check this conflict of interest, be uniform in all agencies. It is also strange that since 24 October the Commission has not come up with any concrete measures (because that is what the Commissioner promised, that it would also speak to the new Commission and come up with concrete measures).  Of course, the regulation of European financial markets, the way of regulation, the way of supervision influences the entire internal market and I do not understand the decision of the Council and the Commission to have this indifference in assessing the conflict of interest. I also do not understand how a Commissioner can say that, after employment, post-employment, we check whether there is a conflict of interest. We are talking about prevention, we can check ahead, and the specific case brought up in this question Must be resolved urgently and this gentleman cannot be hired if he has recognised conflicts of interest, in fact.

name: Marek Paweł BALT
text: – Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. It is in the interest of the European institutions, inter alia, to prevent abuses and violations of the law by subordinate institutions. He wonders about the transfer in which Mr Farkas, who held an important audit post, suddenly becomes the director of an association that can lobby and influence the EU institutions. This gives rise to a suspicion of being able to exercise influence for the benefit of the aforementioned association as well as of the other institutions concerned.  It is in the interest of the European Commission and the European Parliament to monitor and prevent such cases. If so, can we count on a report on such an audit?

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, in relation to the conflict of interest, I would say that it is the source of the most important fraud that is taking place in the economic system of the European Union. Conflict of interest is a subject that remains in the news. Unfortunately, conflict of interest is regulated and interpreted differently in the Member States of the European Union.  It is the failure to comply with strict criteria in the regulation of conflict of interest that also differentiates us from country to country. There are some countries that pay particular attention to the conflict of interest, others have relaxed legislation. But the conflict of interest also affects the work of local government, central government.  That is why I propose to the Commission that, within a reasonable time, it should come up with a proposal to regulate the conflict of interest, universally valid in all European Union states and in all areas, because this is the source of corruption at European Union level.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab On the canvas of this very interesting discussion, I would like to raise the subject without immediately waiting for the answer that the whole of Europe is talking about. Everyone knows that we are building a New Green Deal, that huge amounts of money will be allocated to it. I see, because I am involved in the legislative process, a great deal of interest in this process by various lobby groups and financial markets. I would therefore like to ask that, at this stage, we clearly separate the people who are working in this legislative process from those who will later (I am thinking of later advisers from different companies) use or advise in collecting this money or implementing the huge financial resources that will be available. I am afraid that there may be financial bubbles and all sorts of scams, so at this stage please pay attention to this.

name: Janez Lenarčič
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I listened very carefully to the comments that you made on this important matter. First of all, I would like to assure you all that, first, the Commission is not indifferent to issues of potential conflicts of interest, and, second, we are certainly not taking lightly this, or any other, case involving a potential conflict of interests. It is not for the Commission to play the role of an advocate for a decision taken by an independent body, the Board of Supervisors of the EBA, but we do feel that we can shed some additional light. I’ll try to do so in view of the comments just made.  First of all, the representative of the Commission on the Board of Supervisors, who, I repeat, does not have voting rights, tried to get restrictions which were as strict as possible because there was indeed the finding that this case involved a conflict of interest. The Board of Supervisors looked very carefully into this matter and was of the view that the conflict of interest could be managed by imposing additional restrictions, such that go beyond the minimum condition applied to senior officials. So the length of the period prohibiting the lobbying contracts vis—à-vis the former staff is twice the duration as compared to the minimum, and so on. I won’t go into the details of the restrictions now, but the Board had to weigh and find the right balance between the interests of the public, on the one hand, and the rights of a person to pursue their work. An important question was raised among others: who would monitor and ensure the implementation and enforcement of this decision? I would like to note that the decision by the EBA Board of Supervisors includes a provision on implementation. The restrictions that were imposed will be communicated to the EBA staff and they will be required to report to the Chairperson on any contacts with Mr Farkas after he has left the service of the EBA. Furthermore, the EBA is subject to an obligation to inform the public each year on the implementation of the prohibition on lobbying and advocacy, including a list of the cases assessed. Mr Farkas, as any other active or former staff member, is subject to the Staff Regulations and disciplinary proceedings could be opened against him in case of breach, including after his departure from the EBA. Were the EBA Board of Supervisors or the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to become aware of evidence of failure, following an administrative investigation and eventual disciplinary proceedings, Mr Farkas could be subject to disciplinary measures, as defined in the Staff Regulations. I think this explains that not everything is left to chance. There are provisions in place that should ensure that these restrictions are properly implemented. To conclude, let me reiterate that the Commission ensures – or tries to ensure – that high ethical standards are in place across all the agencies by having in place a harmonised legal framework. However, it is the responsibility of, in this case, the EBA Board of Supervisors to implement this legal framework by taking decisions independently on post-employment restrictions, in accordance with its founding regulation and with the Staff Regulations. It is also the responsibility of the EBA Board of Supervisors to ensure that these decisions are properly monitored and their implementation enforced. Finally, the Commission is always seeking to improve the existing framework. The existing ethical framework is the subject of constant review. We are looking for possible improvements, including, as I mentioned earlier, by setting up an independent ethical body and, I repeat, we are looking forward to close collaboration with the European Parliament, the European Ombudsman and other institutions in this process.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I have received one motion for a resolution tabled in accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure. I close the debate. The vote will take place today, Thursday 16 January 2020.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on Burundi, in particular freedom of expression (2020/2502(RSP).

name: Ellie CHOWNS
text: author. – Madam President, colleagues, Burundi is a beautiful country which has seen more than its fair share of tragedy. The report of the Truth and Reconciliation Commission released this week identified more than 4 000 mass graves, with over 142 000 victims. In such a context, the role of human rights defenders, the role of freedom of expression in an unfettered press, are even more important. They are cornerstones of democracy and of sustainable peace building.  We’ve been prompted to debate this topic today by the most recent example of Burundian government repression of freedom of expression. Burundi’s Public Prosecutor, on 30 December, asked for a 15-year jail term for four journalists and their driver, Christine Kamikazi, Agnès Ndirubusa, Térence Mpozenzi, Egide Harerimana, and Adolphe Masabarakiza, who was simply driving them.  They were arrested in October when they were covering clashes between rebel and government forces and they’ve been accused of complicity with undermining the State.  I understand the only evidence that’s been presented in the trial is a single WhatsApp message. They are not the first. In July 2016, another reporter, Jean Bigirimana disappeared and has not been heard from since. In 2015 journalist Christophe Nkezabahizi, his wife and two children were murdered in their home in Bujumbura and there has been no adequate follow up.  Human rights activist, Germain Rukuki, a member of Action by Christians for the Abolition of Torture (ACAT) was sentenced to 32 years in prison last year and Nestor Nibitanga, was also sentenced to five years.  We call on the government to, immediately and unconditionally, release these journalists and these human rights defenders. There are upcoming elections in 2020 – an important point for the country.  I welcome the fact that President Pierre Nkurunziza has said that he will not seek re-election, but in order for there to be credible elections, major changes – considerable improvements to the political and human rights situation – are needed.  I urge Burundi in the strongest possible terms to change course and create the conditions needed for an open and vibrant democracy and I salute the efforts of the journalists and human rights defenders who are working for that end.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: author. – Madam President, Burundi is one of the poorest countries of the world and our very detailed draft joint resolution portrays the situation there in the time preceding the presidential and general elections. The situation of both human rights defenders and media representatives is really dire and we cannot imagine free elections without them being available for the general public, to present information, genuine, reasonable and reliable information. I thank my colleagues for the very good text of the resolution.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Author. Madam President, the political crisis in Burundi is having a devastating impact on the people of Burundi, who are being violated by their economic rights but also their fundamental rights. Since 2015, these fundamental rights, such as the right to vote, have been in difficulty. People considered political opponents in the broadest sense have been threatened, driven into exile, imprisoned and sometimes even subjected to summary executions. The right to freedom of expression has also been undermined and space for civil society and the media is increasingly restricted in this country. On 22 October 2019, Christine Kamikazi, Agnès Ndirubusa, Terence Mpozenzi and Egide Harerimana, four journalists from the Iwacu group, as well as their driver Adolphe Masabarakiza were arrested and charged with complicity in endangering state security. In addition, Jean Bigirimana, a journalist with the Iwacu group, has been missing since July 2016. And in relation to these arrests and killings, there are systematic failures of the authorities which constitute a violation of the law regarding the protection of citizens by the state. We strongly condemn intimidation and arbitrary arrests. We call for the immediate release of Iwacu journalists and anyone imprisoned for exercising their right to freedom of expression. In order to prevent the situation in the region from escalating, we also call on the African Union to send its human rights monitors to Burundi and call on the United Nations to launch impartial investigations into those suspected of committing human rights violations. Finally, we call on the Member States of the Union to provide financial assistance to Burundi's civil society actors and call on EU diplomats to ensure that the European Union's human rights guidelines are respected, by observing and visiting the trials of political prisoners and human rights defenders. Finally, let us strongly reaffirm that there must be sanctions that are maintained against Burundi, targeted sanctions that have been decided by the Council and which should not be lifted today: this would be a disastrous political message in relation to the situation in Burundi.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: Author. – Madam President, we are witnessing a widespread setback around the world of civil and political rights, which is manifesting itself differently.  In Europe, through laws criminalizing protest and widespread increase in hatred, manifested in the far right.  In Latin America, with lawfare, with different direct attacks on different people, defenders of the territory and the environment.  In the Middle East, with the creation of a black hole of impunity in which international conventions on humanitarian law and international law are swept away.  Africa is not a continent that escapes this dangerous trend. Today we are talking about Burundi, where the political and economic crisis has been deepening for four years, where human rights violations are essentially political in nature, from the Government, and the abolition of civil liberties is intensified in a period prior to the 2020 presidential and legislative elections. The immediate and unconditional release of all detainees who freely express their views is necessary. Violence, human rights violations and political intimidation against civil society and opposition must cease immediately. Decisive action must be taken for freedom of expression by abolishing measures taken against NGOs and the media; respect international human rights and anti-torture treaties. The cessation of these human rights violations is the precondition for the Government of Burundi, through neighbouring countries, to establish a peaceful political dialogue process.  But none of this can happen if we don't get involved in Europe. And Europe also needs to decide what role it wants to play in today's world. That's why we need concrete action. Europe must demonstrate its commitment to peace by granting refugee status also to Burundian asylum seekers, as recommended by the United Nations, and also to work on official development aid on the ground, also to enable neighbouring countries to be able to take in refugees, and ensure that European companies operating in Burundi respect international standards.  The European Union's relationship with Africa has always been complicated. We're not linked to a story we can be proud of. That is precisely why it is time for Europe to begin a relationship with foreign policy objectives aligned with the interests of the African population, focused on human rights, sustainable development and democracy.

name: Arba KOKALARI
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Freedom of expression and independent media are a prerequisite for democracy and for a free society. There are many of us here who take seriously the fact that there is a downward trend in the world. According to the World Press Freedom Index, the number of countries around the world that have a free press is decreasing.  I am very concerned about this situation, and Burundi in particular is one of the countries where free media and free press and civil society are subjected to great repression. Threats and violence against human rights activists and journalists are becoming more frequent. The media is largely state-controlled. Last October, four journalists and their driver were arrested while trying to do their work.  The world cannot just watch these violations take place every day around the world. We must act, we must increase political pressure on Burundi. Burundi must ensure that it fulfils its international commitments and release these journalists immediately.  What can the EU do? Well, we in the EUROPEAN Union must support civil society, and we must extend sanctions against those who commit human rights violations in Burundi. It is about our opportunity and our responsibility to ensure that we have a world in which human rights and democracy work and where freedom is fought.

name: Jan-Christoph OETJEN
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Elections are to be held in May of this year and, as is so often the case, the situation in these countries is getting worse. In Burundi, however, the situation has been tense for several years. Human and civil rights are being trampled underfoot in Burundi, opposition figures, journalists, human rights activists are being arrested, brought to justice, and sometimes simply murdered. We must not look away at this point, but we must raise our voices and defend these people. The specific cases have just been mentioned by Chown's colleagues and Arena. I do not want to repeat them at this point, but I would like to join in the call for the allegations against these arrested persons to be dropped immediately. They must be released without any conditions. That is the demand that we, here as the European Parliament, should be sending loudly to Burundi. Because having a different opinion, reporting critically or advocating human rights is not a crime, but something that is valuable and which we, as the European Parliament, should defend. That is why we are calling to Burundi: release these people, they have done nothing wrong. We must keep up the pressure on the Burundian authorities. That is why the international community must stand strong together and must continue to exert pressure on it. And the Burundian authorities must finally ensure that human rights are respected, that civil rights are respected, that freedom of expression is possible and that free elections can be held in a secure democracy in May this year.

name: Seán KELLY
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa PPE. – A Uachtaráin, táimid ar ais arís sa Bhurúin agus ón am a phléamar an scéal seo ó chianaibh, níl aon scéal maith againn. Drochscéal i ndáiríre, easpa saoirse do lucht an phreasa, easpa cearta daonna do mhuintir na Burúine agus is fiú díospóireacht a bheith againn ar an ábhar seo ar maidin. On 14 March 2016, the EU suspended all direct financial support to the Burundian administration. This arose out of the 2015 presidential elections, which were boycotted by the opposition and which the UN Observatory condemned.  The EU deplores the continued oppression of freedom of speech and freedom of expression in Burundi. In 2018 and 2019, media outlets faced increased harassment by the Burundian authorities when foreign-operating licenses such as that of the worldwide respected BBC were withdrawn. The Burundian authorities continue to subject independent journalists to arbitrary arrests. In the World Press Freedom Index, Burundi is ranked 159th out of 180 countries in 2019. That says it all where freedom of expression and freedom of speech are concerned.  With presidential, parliamentary and local elections taking place in 2020, this remains a huge issue. On 22 October 2019, the Burundian police arrested four journalists on the basis of complicity in threatening state security and a judgment is to be given on those in 30 days. For that reason, it is so important that the European Union and our High Representative take immediate steps and make representations there to ensure that the 15-year prison term suggested is not given to these journalists.  Finally, I would say also that we need to work closer with the East African Community and the African Union to protect the Burundian population. We can only improve on the terrible situation that is there at the moment.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – (start of the intervention with the microphone off) ... freedom of expression in Burundi has been the target of several attacks. The case of journalists and their driver arrested at the end of 2019 is just another in a long list of cases of serious human rights violations committed in this country. The United Nations, through its Secretary-General and the Human Rights Council, has raised serious concerns about the human rights situation in general and respect for freedom of expression in particular: killings, torture, arbitrary detentions and other forms of inhumane treatment are mentioned by the United Nations, all in a climate of widespread impunity. The cases of violation of freedom of expression under discussion today are a reflection of this widespread repression and should merit our vehement disapproval. We therefore call for the release of the four journalists arrested at the end of the year – Christine Kamikazi, Agnès Ndirubusa, Térence Mpozenzi, Egide Harerimana and her driver, Adolphe Masabarikiza – and to create conditions for free and democratic elections next May.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Burundi has been facing multiple crises over the last five years. People considered as opposition are disappearing, being tortured and killed. Journalists are harassed and arbitrarily arrested. There is total impunity for the perpetrators, and thousands of Burundian refugees are fleeing to escape the violence and humanitarian crisis.  In an already dire situation the presidential elections this year risk generating even more instability and potential violence, with people opting to join armed opposition groups. The government must take action now. It must protect its people and restore and uphold their rights to prevent the situation escalating further. It must release the jailed journalists and cease to censure society. The rule of law must be upheld and democracy fostered or the country risks disintegrating further.  Under these circumstances, the EU has had no choice but to suspend financial support to the government of Burundi. But we should not let down the Burundian people. We must strengthen our development cooperation to help relieve the humanitarian crisis, and we must stand ready to offer all we can to support a peaceful electoral process.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, on behalf of the Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance, I would like to take Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I am grateful that we elected representatives in the European Union are paying attention to the situation in Burundi, that we are not allowing it to go on in silence. The situation is beneath all criticism, and the persecution of journalists must stop. The Government of Burundi must release every journalist.  Europe has a vital role to play. We can use our mechanisms and tools to put an end to this situation. And we Greens call on all EU Member States to support civil society organisations, journalists' associations and the women's rights movement in Burundi.  The EU must also work towards the implementation of the Arusha Agreement, so that it becomes a reality. We Greens call on Mr Borrell to provide support to the East African Community in the Burundi dialogues.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I have been to Burundi, as well as to countries that are neighbouring Burundi, that is, Rwanda to the north, Tanzania to the south and east, and also in the Republic of Congo called democratic. So I think I know what the situation is in this country, which – attention! – is a country with a long historical tradition. The kingdom in this country, the Kingdom of Tutsi, was established before a number of European countries were established, including the state that later colonized Burundi, belgium.  It is good that, firstly, we are speaking on this issue, that we are demanding freedom for the journalists there and for free elections this spring. But it is also very important that we are able to show how the pressure mechanism works, namely to withhold financial aid to a country that does not respect human rights.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, the proximity of the electoral process in Burundi has sharpened social and political tensions in the country and highlighted how the state operates with a strong police hand to limit the fundamental rights of citizens as the right to freedom of expression. The state has been boycotting the work of the UN, which works on basic assistance to the populations, and also the work of other NGOs that do so. Freedom of expression is in danger with the arrests and demonstrations made to those who deceit to disalign with official discourse. Several journalists are missing or have been prevented from freely carrying out their work. There is an urgent need to ensure that this year's elections take place freely and fairly, and we call for close monitoring by our External Action Service and European diplomats on the ground. The imposition of sanctions directed by the European Union and the UN should be assessed as soon as possible and put in place as a way of punishing the permanent human rights violations in Burundi.  Reconciliation and political and social peace in Burundi are essential for the country to develop and emerge from the spiral of endemic poverty in which it finds itself.

name: Phil BENNION
text: – Madam President, the people of Burundi continue to suffer from human rights abuses. The United Nations report from September last year showed that the police, the intelligence services and even the youth wing of the governing party have been responsible for the killings, the disappearances and the arbitrary arrests of actual or alleged opposition politicians and their families. One of the first steps to holding human rights abusers to account is freedom of expression, but this too has come under attack in Burundi. The BBC had its licence revoked by the Burundian authorities, which also banned its citizens from providing information to the BBC. Even children are not safe from prosecution. Three schoolgirls were arrested last year for allegedly doodling on the President’s image in their school books. While they were later released, the government warned that future cases would be punished.  More recently, the police arrested four journalists from a Burundian media organisation – and their driver. They are potentially facing 15—year prison terms for just pursuing their profession. We must press the Burundian Government to release these journalists, cease the persecution of independent media and opposition politicians and reverse their suppression of freedom of expression.  Burundi is a signatory to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, in which the protection of freedom of expression is enshrined. This is critical to ensure that the upcoming presidential elections are free and fair, which is the best route to a peaceful and genuinely democratic society.

name: Nathan GILL
text: – Madam President, it seems a little rich to me that we are here, in the European Parliament in Strasbourg, debating freedom of expression in Burundi when actually, because of a rule made by this Parliament this week, I am not free to express myself by having my national flag here, on my desk. Are you really lecturing other nations about their freedom to express themselves, when you are repressing and denying our colleagues here the right to proudly display their national flags? What are you afraid of? Yes, help others to improve their nations, but get your own house in order. We, the British, are leaving, we’re taking our flags with us, but stop being hypocrites and allow other MEP colleagues here to express themselves and their electorates, and their identity by having their national flags on their desks.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, it pains me to follow that presentation, but I want to focus on Burundi and on Agnès Ndirubusa, Christine Kamikazi, Egide Harerimana and Térence Mpozenzi. They were journalists just doing their job, investigating and holding the government to account. Now they face up to 15 years in jail. They were arrested on charges of undermining state security, but really these attacks on media freedom are aimed at preventing the world from knowing about serious human rights abuses happening in Burundi.  So, my questions to the Commission. What will the European External Action Service (EEAS) do to pressure the government to release these four journalists? How will it use its leverage, such as the EUR 400 million allocated in the European Development Fund? And as elections approach in May, how will the Commission ensure that President Nkurunziza acts to protect what is left of freedom of expression in Burundi and that there are free and peaceful elections? This is perhaps my last speech in this plenary and it has been an honour and a privilege to be able to speak up for those who are less able to do so; a platform that I’ve been able to use to speak against human rights abuses around the world.

name: Marek Paweł BALT
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Freedom of expression is an unquestionable value. This freedom can be derived from arguments based on the idea of democracy, from the need to serve the truth and the associated freedom to proclaim ideas, and finally from the autonomy of the individual and fundamental human rights. Unfortunately, the current government in Burundi is blocking the free flow of information while manipulating public opinion. People who seek information outside the country are severely punished, often beaten and raped, and finally sentenced to life imprisonment or murdered. The Burundian Government still does not respect human rights and does not lean towards a democracy that is fragile and sensitive to all dangers. The European Commission and the European Parliament should play a leading role in monitoring the pre-election situation in Burundi, so as to avoid electoral manipulation and, finally, that peace and, with it, freedom of expression can prevail in the country.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 2020 could represent a year of great change for Burundi: presidential elections and parliamentary elections should finally be held on 20 May, after a terrible season, which began with the disputed elections in April 2015. In the meantime, however, Burundi remains the scene of very serious violations of human rights. President Nkurunziza has committed heinous crimes to maintain power against the will of the people, carrying out a bloody repression of demonstrations, which has seen massacres and extrajudicial executions of opponents and members of civil society. Since 1 May 2019, in particular, a long season of political assassinations and threats made by the regime to independent polling stations and political opponents has begun. The space for civil society and the media has been increasingly restricted and many independent activists and journalists face intimidation, arbitrary detention and summary trials. I would like to express my deepest concern at these developments, which presage the violent and undemocratic nature of the forthcoming elections. How can fair and fair electoral competition be guaranteed for opposition parties in the light of a reinforced repression of the independent media? Burundi needs a lasting political solution, but its current government refuses to respect international treaties, the Arusha Agreement of 2000 and the Burundian Constitution itself, undermining any initiative for reconciliation, peace and justice. That is why we need to make the European Union's voice heard more than ever, demanding respect for international treaties and the clause in the Cotonou Agreements on human rights. (The speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: blue-card question. – Colleague, you mentioned the problems in Burundi, but this is not the only country where such things take place, especially in Africa. We discuss these things a lot here in this Parliament. But what do you think, honestly, that the EU can do to really influence issues in these kinds of countries? We know that we have development aid, etc., but to what extent do you think that the European Union can find a really unified voice and influence issues at the global level?

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for this important question. First of all let me say that it is true: it is not the only country, but that’s why it is even more important than ever that we will respect of the human rights clause in the Cotonou agreement. It has never been effectively applied, and above all we must look into not only suspending our cooperation funds, but also eventually implementing targeted sanctions against those responsible for these atrocities. We are speaking in Burundi of a covert genocide because still there is a conflict between the Hutu and Tutsi in the country as happened in Rwanda. And of course let me say that we must try to use our leverage and to ensure a united position of the European countries. We cannot allow some of our Member States to negotiate behind our back, not respecting the official position of the High Representative and, of course, the official position of the EU.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I have listened very carefully to the whole debate and I agree with all my colleagues. The situation in Burundi is indeed very critical and I thank the petitioners of this press for submitting such a report. Especially in the situation mentioned here. In six months, burundi faces two elections – parliamentary and presidential. And we, the European Union, and it is a question for the Commission, for you, Commissioner, to do our utmost to do our utmost through appropriate diplomatic channels, but also through economic instruments, to ensure that these elections are conducted democratically. That should be the aim of today's debate. We can say here how tragic it is, how journalists are treated, with the opposition in Burundi, but the aim of this meeting should be what we do to ensure that there are at least a little democratic elections in May. And the situation will not be easy, although a colleague here has said that the current president does not want to run, so some analysts say that he will still run, which would be contrary to burundi's constitution. So we have a difficult road ahead of us to help Burundi and democratic elections in May.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Mr President at the hearing, I wanted to intervene precisely because it is very good that we are debating in the European Parliament the situation of human rights, freedom of expression everywhere where it is restricted in the world.  Millions of citizens are looking forward to the European Union because we are the home that defends these values. On these principles, the founding fathers have established the European Union and it is vital for us to stand with journalists who do their duty honestly in these countries where democracy is fragile. It is essential, because we have the largest diplomatic corps in the whole world.  The External Action Service needs to get more involved because we have the largest network of diplomats globally and, because we have that authority, people are looking forward to us and we need to do more for Burundi as well.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, last November I had the honour to participate in the ACP-EU Joint Parliamentary Assembly, held in Rwanda, to discuss the future of the European Union's relationship with African countries, essentially after the Cotonou Agreement. However, that same Joint Parliamentary Assembly, the European Commission and the European Parliament as a whole determined that Burundi ⸻they border with Rwanda, which also suffered from the appalling genocide in the mid-1990s⸻ flagrantly violates the Cotonou Agreement, Article 96 thereof, because of the repressive situation that continues. Burundi is one of the poorest countries on earth. 50% of its budget depends on foreign aid and, even under these conditions, the European Union maintains financial support from EUR 91 million to EUR 120 million, essentially humanitarian. We therefore have the authority and duty to demand that impending elections in Burundi ⸻presidencial, parliamentary and local elections⸻ take place in an atmosphere where systematic repression of journalists and human rights defenders, imprisonment, arbitrary detention, enforced disappearances and systematic torture are not tolerable. We have all the moral authority and we support the Commission to exercise it.

name: Janez Lenarčič
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I share your concern about the situation in Burundi. I recall that, last December, the Council confirmed the need to maintain appropriate measures, according to Article 96 of the Cotonou Agreement, against Burundi.  The EU believes that the Burundi crisis should remain high on the international agenda and we will continue to work with our partners in the United Nations, the African Union and African regional organisations. There are signs that tensions could increase further in the run-up to elections that are now foreseen for 20 May. Violations and abuses of human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and freedom of association, persist across the country.  The case of four journalists from Iwacu who have been imprisoned was mentioned by many here and I would like to assure you that the EU is keeping this issue very high on its agenda with the Burundi authorities. We have been raising this and coordinating with our like-minded partners. We will not let this issue just go away.  The Commission of Inquiry on Burundi, in its latest report in September, denounced the persistence of a climate of fear and intimidation of all persons who do not support the ruling party. The Commission also raised red flags at the serious human rights violations that were committed, some of them constituting international crimes. I do not, however, believe that we should just accept as inevitable that things can only get worse from now on. That is not in anybody’s interests and most certainly not in the interests of Burundi and its people.  I wish to assure you that the European Union has no intention of abandoning Burundi. Through its development cooperation, the European Union remains strongly engaged in the country, also working with civil society and human rights defenders and building up the resilience of the population. In the next four months, the time leading up to the elections, it will be crucial that Burundi strives to ensure a credible, transparent and inclusive electoral process, open up political and civic space and bring an end to human rights violations and impunity.  Respect for the spirit and the letter of the Arusha Agreement is key. I encourage Burundi to take this path, noting that there are elements to build on, such as a Code of Conduct broadly supported by political parties and the President’s reconfirmed announcements not to run for a fourth mandate. If Burundi chooses this path, it can count on the readiness of the European Union to accompany it.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place after the debate.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Nigeria, in particular the recent terrorist attacks (2020/2503(RSP)).

name: Assita KANKO
text: author. – Madam President, ‘Bring back our girls’. Remember six years ago this hashtag brought the world together to call upon the Islamic terror group Boko Haram to release the hundreds of schoolgirls they abducted. It is heart breaking to think that more than 100 of them have still not returned to their homes today. It’s a terrible fate for them and for their families. The pain is easy to imagine.  Nigeria has been subjected to sectarian and religious violence for far too long. It’s yet another country in sub-Saharan Africa that sees its economic and political potential wasting away. Nigeria with its oil wealth would be a leading example in the region. Instead, almost every day Nigerians are dying at the hands of violence and terror. Millions run for their lives. Millions more live every day in fear. Europe must continue to support the people of Nigeria and promote the regional cooperation and encourage further reforms like for security and in the army.  Our determination and efforts to end religious and sectarian violence and to protect women in the region must never waiver so we can stop the poisonous and destructive spread of terror.

name: Erik MARQUARDT
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Many thanks also to my fellow Members for being able to agree on such a broadly agreed resolution in a short time. I believe it is important that we here in Parliament draw attention to this humanitarian emergency. Since the start of the Boko Haram insurgency, 36,000 people have been killed, the country is now ranked third in the international terrorism index behind Afghanistan and Iraq, and 2 million people have been displaced in the north-east of the country alone. 7 million people in Nigeria are in need of humanitarian aid, and I think it is important that we also say: yes, in Nigeria Christians are persecuted because of their religion. However, I believe that we would do well to make it clear in our resolution – and we are doing so – that it is not a war of religions in Nigeria. It is a question of the distribution of resources, and we are also making it clear that the climate crisis will already have an impact on living conditions today and not at some point, that the climate crisis is already having a decisive influence on economic stability and local conflicts. Terrorist organisations are hitting fertile ground where people have no prospects, little orientation. We should also be clear: perhaps we can do a little better to help on the ground. I have the feeling, and I believe it can be made clear from figures, that our development policy on the ground is too often shaped by our own interests and not necessarily just by the interests of the Nigerian people. That is why it is good that we are once again saying in the resolution that development cooperation on the ground should serve precisely the objectives of combating poverty and not any other objectives. It may be that we want fewer people to flee Nigeria, but I think it is reprehensible for us to pretend that we can simply close the borders in Nigeria, to build pressure on the country. The Correspondent, a Dutch newspaper, recently presented this in great detail. I believe that this resolution is important. It is also important that we increasingly focus on how we can help the people on the ground, that they no longer have to flee, rather than simply preventing them from fleeing.

name: Lars Patrick BERG
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I have tabled a separate resolution because the attacks on Christians in Nigeria, in particular the beheadings on 26 December 2019, constitute a barbaric and unspeakably vicious act of violence. This House is happy to speak about human rights violations, but when it comes to the systematic murder of Christians, Parliament seems to be reluctant to speak out. I therefore appeal to you that, in the joint resolution, we now recognise and condemn these acts of terror and that everyone recognises the urgency of action. We should talk about the terrible deeds of the Christmas season: attacks on Christians in the name of Islam. These murders must not be concealed again, citing all sorts of other issues. The condemnation of Islamist terrorist acts against Christian communities must be clearly stated. I repeat: these people were beheaded because they were Christians. They were cruelly and brutally executed by members of a terrorist militia. I welcome a debate on the security situation in Nigeria, but attention should be focused on the plight of the threatened Christian communities in Nigeria and West Africa.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: Author. – Madam President, the terrible damage done to Nigeria by ten years of armed conflict with Islamic radicalism and boko haram's presence in the country is enormous: some 36,000 dead since 2009, almost 2 million displaced, more than 7 million people in humanitarian emergency. These impacts, which can be measured, are added to cases of physical and sexual violence against women and girls, the lack of access to education and health care caused by conflict and the whole spiral of poverty and insecurity that results from it. Recent terrorist attacks reinforce the urgency of implementing the state's counter-terrorism strategy, stabilizing the territory, protecting its nationals, Muslims and Christians, from Islamic radicalism and preventing law enforcement authorities from continuing to be complicit and perpetrators of crimes against humanity. There is an urgent need to empower civil society and NGOs working on the ground to respond to malnutrition and ensure basic health care, especially for pregnant women and children. Climate change sharpens the situation experienced by the population, and it is essential to work in the medium term to create conditions for access to the country's available natural resources, which will be an essential part of peace-building as well as economic and social stability in the region. Migration movements in Nigeria and neighbouring countries create additional problems, so targeted and coordinated action by the international community is needed, as well as enhanced cooperation on counter-terrorism measures. Combating all forms of religious radicalism and terrorist groups operating in Nigeria must be a national priority, but also our priority. Internal security in Nigeria is also our security. In the global village in which we live, what is happening on the African continent has direct influence around the world, and in the European Union in particular. We must therefore all join forces to combat this scourge.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Madam President, Nigeria is Africa's largest oil producer and is yet another example of a resource-rich country, but in which more than half of its population lives in poverty. Moreover, violence in the country is extreme. There are more than two million forced displaced persons. Women and girls suffer rape and sexual exploitation and thousands of minors are recruited by Boko Haram or imprisoned by the state. A state that has been criminalizing humanitarian aid and the work of NGOs for months, using the alibi for the alleged counter-terrorism. Nowhere can anti-terrorism laws be an excuse to overturn rights and freedoms.  It is necessary to remind this Parliament of respect for international humanitarian law and the principles of neutrality of official development aid from European funds. We must hold our companies accountable for human rights violations and environmental destruction. Now, as we talk so much in this Parliament about the European Green Pact, we cannot hide that the Niger Delta is one of the most polluted regions in the world thanks to multinationals, also Europeans. Poverty, violence, economic expoliation are pushing people to flee Nigeria. Thousands of people risk their lives on migration routes and are victims of slavery and sexual exploitation. We address migration phenomena only from their consequences and with a securitarian approach, erecting walls.
