We would do well to focus on the causes, responsibilities and necessary coherence of all European policies and the actions of European multinationals in Nigeria and other countries in the global south to understand precisely these migration flows. It is not enough to approve trust funds for Africa. The important and urgent thing is to take a 180-degree shift to European economic and geostrategic policies on the African continent.  Ladies and gentlemen, neither alms nor empty words. Let us be consistent with our policies and consistent with our actions. Let's change course. Let's have another policy for Africa.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, while we were proposing a resolution in the European Parliament on the situation in Nigeria regarding the 11 Christians executed, another monstrous act has taken place in Nigeria. Last Wednesday night, Nigerian militants kidnapped four missionaries directly from their seminary. If we add this kidnapping to murders, massacres, violence, oppression, robberies, forced evictions and other crimes against humanity, we get a terrible picture of how and what is actually happening in Nigeria today. More than 6,000 murdered Christians, Muslims and others in Nigeria over the past five years, 3,600 girls and boys in military prison camps with appalling living conditions, 2 million people on the run. These are just shards of what is happening in Nigeria today. The state has no control over militant, mostly radical Islamist armed groups. Boko Haram is one of them, one of the largest to carry out such infamy in Nigeria that there is talk of targeted genocide, and we can only compare these infamies to a Nazi or communist regime. Nigeria is now experiencing exactly what was going on in Iraq or Afghanistan. The Nigerian Government must be constantly alerted to this genocide and asked to try to find a solution to this situation, because it is not only possible to accept, but something needs to be done about it.

name: Phil BENNION
text: author. – Madam President, Nigeria has been very close to being a failed state now for decades, largely due to petty squabbles between the two main political parties. This has led to a complete failure to address the real problems the country faces. For instance, despite some advances by the military, Boko Haram remains a threat to security in the northeast region. We have abductions, suicide bombings, attacks on civilian targets by Boko Haram, people are still getting killed, and of course Boko Haram also target their attacks across the border in Chad and in the Cameroon. Decades of old communal conflict between nomadic herdsmen and settled farmers in the middle belt have recently intensified and further exacerbated the security situation in the country. Women and children are the most vulnerable in this conflict. Children often are recruited by the terrorist groups and used as child soldiers or suicide bombers. Farmers are getting killed and others are getting displaced as a result of all this violence. Civil society is left to lead the campaigns against arbitrary arrests, detention and torture, but it should be the Nigerian authorities themselves which guarantee the respect for human rights in the country and lead this fight. President Buhari was re-elected in 2019 on the promise of defeating violent extremism undertaken by terror groups such as Boko Haram. It’s high time to concentrate all of the government’s efforts to keep that promise, developing and implementing a comprehensive strategy. A strategy has been developed, but it’s not been implemented. The External Action Service of the EU and the Member States need to help through technical assistance. In this way we should strongly support Nigeria’s efforts in their fight against terrorism.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, Nigeria is home to West Africa’s largest Christian community with over 80 million Christians. This is about half of the country’s population. Historic rivalry between the Muslim north and Christian south of Nigeria intensified with the spread of radical Islam. For more than 10 years, violent extremist and jihadist groups, such as Boko Haram and Islamic State in West Africa province, terrorised the country. They attacked Nigerian police, military, schools, public institutions and religious buildings. According to a humanitarian organisation, more than 6 000 Christians have been murdered since 2015 by jihadist groups.  The latest reports date from last week, 8 January, when Fulani Muslim herdsmen attacked the predominantly Christian village of Kulben in central Nigeria and killed 13 civilians. Also at the end of December, we witnessed several attacks on Christian villages causing the death of over 30 people. Responsibility for these actions has been claimed by Islamic State in West Africa province as retaliation for the death of Islamic State leader Abu Bakir Al-Baghdadi in Syria. Although the Nigerian President, a Muslim, condemned the atrocities, the announced governmental measures to prevent further violence lack efficiency. Nigerian security forces often seem to neglect the persecution of Christians.  We discuss case after case of violent actions against religious minorities. It is time that the international community recognised the persecution of Christians around the world. Africa is a deeply religious continent and it happens too often that misconceptions about other religions are used to instigate hate and terror. The European Union should use its financial instruments to invest in development of the region, leading to the protection of religious minorities. The EU should also increase its focus on inter-religious dialogue in its diplomatic relations with third countries.  A month ago, Parliament awarded the Sakharov Prize to a Muslim martyr, and with a symbol like this we should encourage countries like Nigeria to recognise and recompense the damages done to a church in need that is left alone. We should not be ashamed to call the crime by its name.

name: Maria ARENA
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D - Madam President, Nigeria is the most populous country in Africa with more than 200 million inhabitants, with a forecast of 500 million inhabitants by 2050. It is also the largest economic force in Africa, earning it the name of the giant of Africa. Nigeria faces many tensions: Boko Haram, which is trying to occupy the northeast and is the author of terrorist attacks that have killed thousands, but also millions of displaced people, for more than a decade; tensions between herders and farmers, which is neither an ethnic conflict nor a religious conflict, but the result of climate change, which pushes herders to occupy the more fertile land, currently occupied by farmers. This conflict is also bloody because of the flow of arms from Libya: the Libyan conflict is therefore having an effect on the Sahel region and Nigeria. The answer must therefore be comprehensive. First, support for the Libyan solution and control of the arms embargo on that region. Secondly, a guarantee that the exploitation of Nigeria's natural resources (oil, gas, but also metals) will allow people to develop. I will recall here the case of Shell, which was attacked by local people because Shell was the author of significant pollution and theft from oil resources. Thirdly, urgent humanitarian assistance also for the ten million people affected by this instability. Fourth, a control of global crime linked to trafficking: drugs, weapons, or prostitution, facilitated by global financial systems that allow tax evasion at the Nigerian level. And finally, the European Union must consider Nigeria as a priority partner in its Union-Africa strategy, because Nigeria's stability is paramount for the region: for the Sahel, Chad, Cameroon, Niger, which are its neighbours (4,000 kilometres of borders), but also for the Gulf of Guinea, which is now the place of all trafficking , and also for the entire African continent. Therefore, Nigeria must remain a privileged partner.

name: María Soraya RODRÍGUEZ RAMOS
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, Nigeria is the third country in the world most affected by terrorism, behind only Iraq and Afghanistan. As has already been said, ten years of Boko Haram violence, aggravated by conflict and ethnic violence between religions ⸻musulmans, Christians⸻ and, lately, also by the struggle for scarce resources between farmers and nomadic herders. In this context of nigeria's emergency of violence, the situation is exacerbated by the most vulnerable, women and children. Women experience a situation of widespread discrimination and violence, such as genital mutilation and child marriages. But let me particularly cite the situation of children, who are in a dramatic situation. They are recruited by terrorists for use in suicide bombings, but also detained by the military in Nigeria, accused of collaboration with terrorism with little evidence. According to international organizations, three thousand and six hundred children ⸻a half, girls⸻ have been detained and the army has consistently denied access to military detention centres. In this regard, we call on the Nigerian authorities to make these children available to civil authorities. We recall that the response in the fight against terrorism, as well as its judicial and police framework, must fundamentally protect human rights and civilians, and especially the most vulnerable. In this regard, we encourage the international community, and especially the Commission and the Member States, to continue to support the construction of peace in this country technically and with all efforts.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in general indifference in Nigeria, thousands of Christians are mercilessly massacred by hordes of Islamic fundamentalists. Terrorism has not yet been eradicated, and what is happening in Nigeria, helpless in the face of jihadist guerrillas, is proof of this. Only a few days ago, the jihadist group Boko Haram released a video of 11 Christian prisoners being brutally murdered: a brutal murder perpetuated on Christmas Day, a real gesture of defiance of Western Christianity. According to humanitarian agencies, at least 30 000 civilians have been killed and 30 million displaced since the jihadist offensive began in 2009. On the part of the European institutions, which promote peace, tolerance and mutual respect, nothing concrete has been done to stop this continuing barbarity, which every day endangers the lives of millions of innocent people, whose only fault is that of being Christians. Islamist fanaticism is devouring the country. Not only is the Boko Haram movement, affiliated with Isis, holding northern Nigeria hostage: in recent years guerrillas motivated by religious fanaticism, such as the Fulani shepherds, have been killing and raiding entire villages in the centre of the country with the aim of Islamising Nigeria by force. This long trail of blood must be stopped as soon as possible. Europe must not let its guard down. Defending Christians in Nigeria means defending the West from the brutality of Islamist fanaticism.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Nigeria is a country with a great history. After all, more than two thousand years ago iron was smelting there and refined terracotta sculptures were created. Cities in the north of the country, such as Kano and Katsina, have more than a thousand years of history. And what does Boko Haram, the official name of Jama'atu Ahlis Sunna Lidda'Awati Wal-Jihad, do with this country? What is Nigeria's image in the world now by persecuting, killing, murdering hundreds of Christians? I think our voice today should sound particularly important. We cannot idly look at what these crescent terrorists are doing with Christians and not only. It is our moral duty. We cannot remain silent on this matter. We must loudly, across divisions, demand that the Nigerian authorities fight hard against Islamic terrorists.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: Mr President, the European Union must now draw a line under. The misery inflicted on Christians in Nigeria in particular is unacceptable. That is what the High Representative for Foreign Policy must now do: make it clear to the government in Abuja that this is no longer possible. Not words, but deeds. It is now high time to put trade and other relations with Nigeria on hold if the government continues to fail to protect Christians and tackle Boko Haram. European companies must also be presented with a mirror. It can no longer be so to make money from this country where corruption and abuse of power dominate. The time for fine statements and hollow statements is over.  For years, Christians in Nigeria have been in the eu. We all know the 270 Christian girls from Chibok who were kidnapped by Boko Haram in 2014. 112 of them are still not back and the girls who came back were often raped and traumatized. Boko Haram's crimes have been going on for years. Christian pastors have also been regularly kidnapped. Nigerian Bishop Matthew Hassan Kukah last week sharply condemned the violence against Christians in his country, saying: "The only difference between the government and Boko Haram is that the latter has a bomb." Pruning commentary from this bishop. Indeed, Prime Minister Buhari said in 2015 that he would tackle terrorism. They were hollow words. Now the European Union must stand up to this injustice. Pull out all the stops to get the government in Nigeria to tackle Boko Haram, and help them do so.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171(8) of the Rules))

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleagues, Christians are in fact the most persecuted religious group in the world and that is a topic which has not really addressed in the western and especially in the European media. Why is that the case? Why are these persecutions against Christians usually not talked about? Why is the focus more on the persecutions of other religious groups and what can we as MEPs in your opinion, do to change this kind of public perception?

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, I fully agree with the colleague. Systematically, the repression and murder of Christians in Nigeria is not given enough media attention. That is why these kinds of debates are important. And I would also like to say to my colleague that the Intergroup on Freedom of Religion and Faith and Religious Tolerance has now been re-established. We are starting with this intergroup and I have already heard that this issue will be important on the agenda of that intergroup: persecution of Christians, including in Nigeria. We should not be playing hide-and-seek here: this is a crucial issue. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 171(8) of the Rules))

name: Maria ARENA
text: 'blue card' question. I take note of your willingness to ask companies to behave in a way that is respectful of the people. The only thing is that your group, the EPP Group, systematically votes against reasoned care measures that concern European companies operating in countries such as Nigeria or countries in conflict. Does that mean that your group will now vote in favour of the proposals that are being made on the reasoned diligence of the companies that are acting in these countries today?

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" answer. – The colleague is absolutely right. When we talk about human rights and religious freedom, we must also tackle the countries that violate human rights and religious freedom. That applies to Nigeria, that applies to Saudi Arabia, that applies to India, you name it all. And the missionary work that you and your group have yet to do in certain areas will also be done by me and my group, to ensure that we ultimately take action in the field of human rights and religious freedom. Please do the same, we'll work together.

name: Jackie JONES
text: – Madam President, we wholeheartedly condemn any terrorist attack regardless of where it happens but especially this one in Nigeria as well. Human rights abuses against women and children are the most pervasive in the world. They’re always the most vulnerable. They’re always the ones targeted right at the forefront of it and we must do everything we can to protect them throughout the world and especially in Nigeria. We saw lots of girls being trafficked many years ago and some of them are still missing. The Multinational Joint Task Force has to go forward and has to do its work in conjunction, in my view, with the African Union and all the actors that are on the African continent.  I want to just say, for the last speech in the European Parliament in Strasbourg, that I want to thank every single person who represented Wales very positively, sat in this seat throughout the time that the European Parliament had direct elections. I want to thank all staff members, past and present for all the work they’ve done on behalf of the Welsh people and the UK people and I want to thank all of those pro-European groups in Wales and around the UK who have sprung up as a result of this terrible referendum result. Keep up the good work. We will be back one day I hope and to the European Parliament and parliamentarians in particular, they’ve been fantastic colleagues, thank you very much and ‘courage’.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: And we would like to thank you.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, Boko Haram has been terrorising Nigeria for over a decade now. More than 36 000 people have been killed and the power of Boko Haram and other terrorist groups is only increasing. While the attacks by these groups are already a serious cause for concern, Nigeria further faces ethnic, religious and communal violence. To make matters worse, these crimes are being carried out with impunity. Fearing for their lives, thousands of Nigerians are fleeing their homes and need aid. As the security risks involved have led to humanitarian organisations leaving, the Nigerian Government must step up to fulfil its duty towards its citizens to protect them, to guarantee their human rights and uphold the rule of law. In an already unstable situation, the government must also de—escalate religious and communal tensions immediately.  Terrorism, however, as we know, knows no borders. The EU and the international community must continue to do everything it can to support the fight against terrorism in Nigeria and the region as a whole.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Madam President, Islamist infiltration into West Africa seems to have found its most terrifying climax in Nigeria: attacks, kidnappings and summary executions, especially on Christmas Day. Who could now dispute that the Christian religion remains the most persecuted in Africa, as elsewhere? How could it be otherwise when the international community persists in remaining with a weapon at its feet? In the Sahel, France alone is carrying the fight against terrorism over an area of eight million square kilometres comparable to Europe. Worse, the West seems to take great pleasure in putting sticks in the wheels of African states struggling with the Islamist hydra. What about, for example, the loud cries of so many beautiful souls against Nigeria's actions against certain NGOs, even though so many proven examples of collusion, attacks or infiltration of these organizations encourage caution? At a time when Islamism is raping and beheading, there is an urgent need to close ranks because this war will obviously only be won by sovereign nations.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Nigeria, Africa's most populous country with a population of 200 million at the moment, is a potentially very rich country because it has vast natural resources, especially oil. Unfortunately, due to the ongoing corruption process in this country for years, it is one of the poorest countries in the world. 87 million people live in extreme poverty. It is the largest group of inhabitants in the world after India. Undoubtedly, however, the biggest problem in Nigeria is terrorism. According to the Global Terrorist Index, Nigeria is in third place when it comes to this problem, after Iraq and after Afghanistan. Christians are the main victims of Islamic terrorists. Nearly 20,000 people have died in Nigeria in a decade and two million have had to leave.  Today we call on President Buhari, who has ruled Nigeria since 2015, to finally start effectively protecting his citizens. (The speaker agreed to answer the blue card question (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "I listen with great curiosity to this much-needed and very important discussion. The European Union must take a very clear stance on these dramas taking place on the African continent. Today we are talking about Nigeria. There has been talk of huge persecutions of Christians. I would like to ask you (I know you are an expert on this issue) whether you do not see an opportunity to resume the debate here in Parliament on the drama of Christians in the world?

name: Klára DOBREV
text: Thank you very much! I'd like to point out that the blue card is really a question. The opinion may be expressed during the period of 'cathc the eye'.

name: Adam BIELAN
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I agree with what Mr Rzońca said. Christians today are the most persecuted religious group in the world. Today we are discussing what is happening in Nigeria, but in October we discussed the situation in Egypt. There, too, Christians are persecuted. Yes, I believe that in this term of office, like the previous term of office, we should have a debate in the European Parliament on the situation of Christians in the world.

name: François-Xavier BELLAMY
text: Madam President, on 25 December, on Christmas Day, eleven Christians were beheaded. On 8 January, still in Nigeria, four seminarians were abducted: they were between 18 and 23 years old. On the same day, thirteen people died in the attack on a Christian village. All these names are in addition to the 35,000 people who have been victims of jihadism - and Boko Haram in particular - over the past decade in Nigeria. To this there are three reasons: the first is these conflicts that thrive in this country and the fact that nothing is being done to contain them, perhaps because no one sees where wants to see that, behind ethnic wars, is actually playing out one of the new battlefields of Islamism that, at the global level, seeks to divide , to fracture and kill. The second reason is the passivity of the Nigerian government and sometimes even the complicity of certain security forces, which do not intervene. We must put this government before its responsibility, because it has the means to restore civil peace and it must guarantee the rights of minorities. Finally, the third reason is our own fragility, ladies and gentlemen, because in this country, as elsewhere in Africa, the United States is withdrawing, Europe itself is being erased and, in the vacuum we leave, other actors are taking the place: China, of course, but also Turkey, Qatar, all those countries that have an economic interest, of course, but also undoubtedly ideological to act in such a region. Europe must be there to ensure respect for the rights of minorities, especially Christian minorities, who need our protection. And to ensure the balance of this region, we must put the Nigerian government before its responsibility: Europe must act today in Nigeria.

name: Tudor CIUHODARU
text: – Madam President, we are in a minefield. This situation has persisted for too long, there are thousands of lives lost and, at the moment, the solutions really do not seem easy to find. I am a doctor, an emergency doctor, I work in Iasi, Romania, at the Emergency Clinical Hospital "Nicolae Oblu" and I believe that every life lost is a tragedy. And unfortunately, when I look at the measures taken for Nigeria, I see that they did not have the efficiency that we would have wanted.  So I am asking publicly today - and I will be voting for this resolution without any problems, even with two hands, because this may save some lives - but we need concrete measures, new geostrategic policies in the region, limiting that hypocrisy that says we are protecting those in Nigeria, but we continue to sell weapons to this region.  And if we are talking about humanitarian aid, know that, as I volunteered in the Ebola campaign, so will I be a volunteer in Nigeria. You can count on me. I wish you success in your efforts, but until then, I see that there is still much to do.

name: Silvia SARDONE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, twelve Christians die every day in the world: they die while in church, on their way to work, in the middle of the street, at school, in kindergartens, while they pray, on pilgrimage. If they are women they are sometimes kidnapped and raped, if they are children they are tortured.  In Nigeria there is a daily slaughter of Christians. In recent years there have been 12 000 Christians killed, 13 000 churches abandoned and destroyed, 1 300 000 displaced. At the end of the year there was the dramatic execution by Isis terrorists of 11 Christians. In Nigeria, Christians, especially in the north of the country, are marginalised, persecuted, attacked, deprived of certain rights at school and also in everyday society. Europe is stammering at all this: no signal, no concrete promise of protection, no serious intervention. As Oriana Fallaci said: "Wake up, West!". Persecuted Christians are asking for help.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 11 Christians shot and then beheaded on Christmas Day, many more killed: a real Christmas of blood in Nigeria. Attacks claimed by the Boko Haram faction, which, with ISWAP, is the armed arm of the Islamic State. Islamist violence has escalated even further under Buhari's new presidency, despite promises. Christians in Nigeria are discriminated against everywhere, even in schools, and are subjected to all kinds of abuses. In 2018, at least 1 200 people were killed and 200 000 displaced as a result of Islamist violence. Christians are being affected because of their faith, yet in the motion for a resolution on which we are going to vote today the word 'Christians' practically disappears and yesterday, in the vote on human rights, the amendments on persecuted Christians were rejected by this House. If we are to be serious and concrete, we must first recognise the victims and the executioners and, finally, we must make our cooperation policy in Nigeria conditional on a finally serious fight against Islamist terrorism.

name: Tomislav SOKOL
text: – Dear Vice President, Christians are today the most provoked religious community in the world. And unfortunately this is not some personal impression of mine, but this fact, this claim is based solely on facts.  Just a few numbers. In 2018, more than four thousand Christians were killed worldwide. But not only that, the world's more than 245 million Christians have been victims of serious persecution for being Christians. That's 1 in 9 Christians in the world. I think we should all really imagine ourselves over that figure and over what she's saying. Unfortunately, perception in the West, especially in the Western media, is quite the opposite. Nigeria, in 2019, unfortunately, has just been at the fore for the persecution of Christians. There, 1,350 Christians were killed there because of religion alone, and more than 6,000 have been killed since 2015. If we look at the period of the last 10 years, more than 12,000 Christians have been killed in Nigeria for being Christians. So I think we should call the problem by its real name. This is not primarily about the conflict between north and south, about the conflict between nomads and farmers, this is about the persecution of Christians who are already almost bordering on genocide. So, of course, it's not just about the murders, it's about confiscating property on the principle of "your country or your blood." It's about rapes, it's about expulsions, it's about systematic persecution of Christians at all levels in Nigeria, and it's a country where Christians make up almost 50% of the population. So they're not a minority. There are more than 80 million of them there, and now let's just imagine what it's like in many countries where they really are a minority.  In other words, the European Union needs to be clear in its stance on the persecution of Christians both in Nigeria and in other countries. Discussions should certainly be opened in this parliament in general on the persecution of Christians in the world and a clear and unequivocal position should be taken without a "finger in the pocket", without hypocrisy, as this is a major problem for the European Union to manifest itself on and which we must fight.

name: Isabella TOVAGLIERI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, genocide hangs over the Christian community in Nigeria. In the last twelve months, Islamic fundamentalists have killed more than a thousand Christians, thanks in part to the complicity of the army, which knows the culprits but does not arrest them. On the anniversary of Christmas, a chilling massacre was carried out against 11 Christians and the massacre was also posted on the web, while a few days ago four seminarians were kidnapped in an area where Shari'a law still applies. Nigeria is in real danger of becoming the new Rwanda or Darfur: since the start of the jihadist offensive, there have now been 30 000 civilian casualties and more than 30 million displaced persons, many of whom are trying to flee by coming to Europe. In 2017 alone, one million and three hundred thousand people left Nigeria. Europe, which has refused to include its Judaeo-Christian roots in the Constitution, cannot make the mistake of doing nothing. Islamic fundamentalists, in fact, pose not only a danger to Nigeria or Nigerian Christians, but also to young Europeans and the future of our children.

name: Bert-Jan RUISSEN
text: Mr President, thousands of people dead, millions displaced, kidnappings, destroyed houses and burned-down churches, that is the sad balance of a decade of violence in Nigeria. The historical rivalry between the Muslim north and the Christian south has greatly increased, especially with the spread of radical Islam: Boko Haram and Islamic State. The long-running conflict between the Fulani herders and Christian farmers in the Middle Belt intensifies, and the intensity and nature of the attacks suggest that there is indeed a very clear religious component in the conflict. In any case, the reality is that the conflict is robbing an increasing number of people of their homes, human dignity and daily life. Meanwhile, the Nigerian Government's approach is deeply flawed. We are quite right to call attention to this in our resolution today. However, the question remains what concrete actions the EU will actually take in the fight against violence in Nigeria.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, this debate we are having here today responds to dramatic events in Nigeria on Christmas Day, in which the Christian faithful were murdered in cold blood just because they wanted to profess their faith. We are talking today and we are having this debate today because this terrible attack on Christians in Nigeria has occurred. It is not an isolated attack, they are attacks that are taking place over time, in the face of the passivity of the authorities in Nigeria. Just to give them some figures of what has happened, more than 6,000 Christians have died since 2015 at the hands of jihadist terrorists in Nigeria.  Of course Nigeria has other dramas and that Boko Haram, of course, is murdering Muslims and Jews. But this case—and this Resolution—is about a drama that is happening, which is persecution of Christians in the world, and we must not turn the spotlight away. And I regret to see how, when this resolution was negotiated, there was more interest, more emphasis, in removing the Christian word from the Resolution than in talking about what had happened, than in focusing on the very tremendous events that are happening. In the last Plenary we are talking about the attacks that occurred in Burkina Faso, and today we regret what happened in Nigeria, and of course I want to send my condolences to the family and friends of the victims.  But I would like to take advantage of the last few seconds I have left to remind you simply of a few figures, so that we understand that we are truly experiencing persecution of Christians in the world, before which the European Union cannot remain impassive. It must react, because we are talking about the values of the West, of the Judeo-Christian values on which the European project was built. Just to keep this in mind, we're talking about 4,305 Christians killed, according to the Open Doors report published in 2020. We can't remain impassive. We must react and defend the values of this Union, the Judeo-Christian values, which are on which this Union is based.  (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Madam President at the hearing, our colleague has presented some earth-shattering figures and, indeed, we need to discuss this issue because Christians are being persecuted and it is shocking that this is happening, including at Christmas, and has called for strong action from the European Union. I would like to ask her to explain exactly what it means to take firm action by the European Union to protect Christians around the world who are being persecuted.

name: Isabel BENJUMEA BENJUMEA
text: "blue card" response. – Madam President, some colleagues in this House have truly said so. We cannot escape the reality of the African continent. We must demand that the authorities, in this case Nigeria, stand up for it, to protect Christians. Let them take action. Don't let them stand by, as we're seeing, unfortunately. As we're seeing how the army, how the security forces are not defending. We must demand these measures.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we will vote in favour in order to condemn the persecution of Christians in Nigeria and because we are at least talking about it, but I cannot ignore the fact that the word 'Christians' has been deleted in the text of this resolution against the men and women who are humiliated, tortured and killed in Nigeria every day, especially during Christmas or 'Season's greetings', as it is hypocritically called in here. Just yesterday, the NGO Open Doors announced that there were 260 million attacks on Christians and 2 983 murders. It is the highest number ever, more than the attack on the Twin Towers, in a single year, in 2019, but there were only 50 nations under observation and in this horrible ranking Nigeria is not even in the top ten.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The situation in Nigeria is extremely difficult. Since 2015, terrorist organisations such as Boko Haram have killed more than 6,000 Christians there. In the face of this enormous threat, it is extremely important that President Muhammadu Buhari condemns the attacks and wants to work to unite society.  Decisive action is needed to guarantee freedom of religion and the safety of citizens. We should therefore call on the Nigerian authorities to fight terrorism and to judge the perpetrators. However, this must be done in compliance with applicable law and human dignity. It is unacceptable to unjustifiably deprive citizens, including children, of their freedom and to keep them without trial without trial in conditions that are in breach of human rights, as the Human Rights Watch report has shown. Such conduct is incompatible not only with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, but also with the Nigerian Constitution itself. Moreover, military action is not enough to combat the threat of terrorism. Terrorist activity is the result of years of radicalisation. In order to really deal with this problem, interreligious dialogue must be conducted, freedom of religion promoted and social inequalities must be combated.  Nigeria is also facing a serious humanitarian crisis Nearly half of the population lives in extreme poverty. The European Union cannot look at this indifferently. Humanitarian aid must continue, but in the face of attacks on volunteers and aid workers, we must at the same time call on the Nigerian authorities to properly secure it. It is also worrying that the Nigerian authorities have abruptly expelled humanitarian organisations, causing thousands of people to be deprived of the aid they desperately need.

name: Robert HAJŠEL
text: – Madam President, Nigeria is indeed a huge country in Africa with enormous human potential, but also in the field of mineral resources, and could soon become a superpower on the territory of Africa, with which we, as the European Union, must have very good relations. In reality, however, Nigeria as such is the victim of huge terrorist attacks, or its inhabitants. Especially, unfortunately, really Christians. Because 80 percent of the victims are Christians. But the victims of terrorists are not only Christians, but also, of course, Muslims and other nationalities, and it must be said that this is a socio-economic conflict, such as a conflict between shepherds and farmers – between those who want to drive others out of the territory in order to graze their own cattle. We, as the European Union, must help them in every way. In the area of humanitarian aid, of course, we must also have a dialogue with the Nigerian Government and force more order in the country as regards respect for human rights and religious freedom.

name: Clare DALY
text: – Madam President, sadly, violence is nothing new in many regions of Nigeria, and for those – and we have them in Ireland – who criticise Nigerian asylum seekers as economic migrants and not worthy of coming to Europe, they should really look at what is happening in that country. The decade-long conflict with armed groups such as Boko Haram has obviously resulted in the deaths of tens of thousands of people, the displacement of two million, and tens of thousands missing, a majority of them children. And how can it be that 50% of the population live in extreme poverty in the country which is the twelfth largest producer of oil? We do have to look at the role of European corporations there, like Total from France, and Shell, a Dutch-British company. There are deals with the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation, which doesn’t pay its taxes and has acted in an environmentally poor way, which has resulted in the deaths of others trying to defend their communities such as the Ogoni people. So we have to join the dots. Is it any wonder this country has descended into barbarism, and is it any wonder that the Iraqi people mourn the death of General Soleimani, who saved them from the type of regime that is prevailing in Nigeria?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, is scéal uafásach é scéal na Nigéire, gan dabht ar bith agus is fiú é a phlé anseo ar maidin. Gan dabht freisin is é grúpa sceimhlitheoireachta Boko Haram an chúis is mó leis na fadhbanna atá sa Nigéir. Aontaím leis na Feisirí Kanko agus Charanzová a deir gur cheart dúinn gach iarracht a dhéanamh chun an céad cailín atá ina gcime ag Boko Haram a ligean saor. Agus freisin cabhrú leis na húdaráis atá ann chun Boko Haram a chosc agus a stopadh. Tá sé sin an-tábhachtach chun dul chun cinn a dhéanamh.  Tír le hacmhainní saibhre agus, ag an am céanna, ceann de na tíortha is boichte í an Nigéir. Is féidir linn a lán a dhéanamh chun cabhrú léi, go háirithe leis na teifigh mar a dúirt Clare Daly, agus leis an athrú aeráide agus, gan dabht ar bith, na Críostaithe; mar sin fadhb eile agus ba chóir dúinn é sin a phlé níos mó amach anseo.

name: Pierrette HERZBERGER-FOFANA
text: Madam President, we are all concerned about the situation in Nigeria, the largest country in Africa. I am thinking in particular of the deteriorating security situation and the widespread violence, which leads to massive displacement of the population and a worsening of humanitarian needs. In 2014, Boko Haram abducted girls and young women and subjected them to all kinds of sexual violence. This violence has increased against women and is also targeting women in border regions such as Cameroon. Recently, nuns have been abducted and imprisoned. We condemn these religious and ethnic attacks. In addition, it is estimated that approximately 1,500,000 people are affected by the inability of humanitarian organizations to access large parts of the region. As a result, 60% of children in hard-to-reach areas are malnourished. The European Union must unite and find new ways to work with the Nigerian government to enable humanitarian aid to be delivered, and above all, this violence against women and religious communities must be stopped. What happened at Christmas must never be repeated again. The European Union must commit itself with the Government of Nigeria to advance respect for humanitarian principles, to intensify dialogue with the authorities in order to put an end to these raids on civilian populations, and also to put an end to this sexual exploitation that has been raging for 10 years. We must demand respect for human rights and freedom of religion.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, we clearly agreed in this debate on the problems that are troubling this unfortunate country. I am ready to support the resolution, although I am also sorry, as some colleagues do, that there is little emphasis on the fact that huge violence is being committed against Christians, and we should accentuate this aspect more in the future.  But what I want to add to the debate has not been very much said here, that often the Nigerian government is very lax about specific attacks, violence, and that government soldiers are often involved in the violence. And here is the role of us, and in particular our Commission, our representatives, to put much more pressure on this Government, in its negotiations with the Nigerian Government, not to turn against ordinary Nigerians. I think that our role and that of the Commission here can be significant, and I wish we could at least help a little bit that the Nigerian Government's fight against terrorism will be more effective in the future, in addition to, say, humanitarian aid, which we are also obliged to provide.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, I condemn the persecution of Christians, of Muslims, of Kurds, wherever they are. The current situation in Nigeria should hold lessons for the imperialists in Europe. The strife is a direct consequence of British colonialism and meddling. The empire’s parting gift to Nigerians was to rig their first elections in favour of the pliant Islamist sultanates in the north, making sure to keep the more independent minded blacks from Yoruba and Igbo regions out of power. The brightest future for Nigeria was crushed and the oil kept flowing. We visited the Christian village of Maaloula in Syria two years ago and where the Christians were directly targeted by the Jihadists, Jihadists that were armed by the West, that were brought into the country, facilitated across the Turkish border. The lack of inconsistency is terrible. The treatment of the Palestinians by the Israelis. The treatment of Muslims in India. The genocide in Yemen. Let’s call a spade a spade.

name: Janez Lenarčič
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, since last year, the human rights and humanitarian situation in Nigeria has significantly deteriorated. Over the past year, terrorist attacks and armed conflict have continued to claim thousands of lives. I want to express our condolences to the families of the victims and our solidarity with the people of Nigeria, and in particular with the communities that have been so deeply affected by the insurgency of non-state armed groups, especially in the north-east of the country. The Boko Haram insurgency has killed more than 36 000 people in Nigeria alone since 2009. An additional challenge is the growing humanitarian crisis. More than two million people are estimated to be internally displaced, more than seven million are in need of humanitarian assistance and more than one million are estimated to be out of humanitarian reach.  The EU is following the situation very closely. We have promoted an integrated, multi-sectoral human rights oriented approach that focuses on peace-building, conflict prevention, humanitarian assistance and social and economic development at community level. The EU continues to stand ready to assist Nigeria in responding to its security, humanitarian and development crisis, in particular around Lake Chad but also in the north west, Middle Belt, Niger Delta and elsewhere, and in all these cases a comprehensive approach that addresses the root causes is necessary, in our view.  The EU is one of the leading contributors of humanitarian aid in Nigeria. It provides immediate assistance to cover the basic needs of the most vulnerable internally displaced people and host communities. Since 2014, the EU has allocated almost EUR 245 million to help people in need in Nigeria, and in 2019 we provided more than EUR 28 million in humanitarian assistance. The EU also aims to build long-term resilience through its development assistance, which addresses the underlying causes of violent conflict, as well as support to basic services and rebuilding livelihoods. Total EU support to the country under the European Development Fund amounts to well over half a billion euros for the period from 2014 to 2019.  Alongside these efforts, we are strongly committed to the fight against radicalisation and violent extremism. We continue to work on strengthening the military’s civilian protection policies and practices, demobilisation, disassociation, reintegration and reconciliation efforts and in delivering improvements to Nigeria’s criminal justice system.  Next week I will travel to Nigeria, including to the northeast, in order to convey a clear signal of the EU’s commitment at the highest political level. Indeed, we are deeply concerned with the issue of shrinking humanitarian access in the northeast and with the breaches of international humanitarian law. Continued dialogue with the authorities therefore constitutes a key priority for me. Furthermore, the next session of the EU-Nigeria human rights dialogue will be held on 18 February and this indicates again our strong commitment to defending human rights in Nigeria through ongoing dialogue and programme.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: The debate is over. A vote is coming soon. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments at 11.43 a.m. until polling time)

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with regard to Rule 196, last Monday the President ordered the clerks to remove the small flags that the representatives of my group had on their table. I believe that this decision is contrary to the rules. We know that the President of Parliament has decided to impose a ban on banners in order to avoid protests with placards in this House and to maintain order. We find it rather ambiguous that the display of small symbols of our national flags is prohibited, so I would like to understand under what rule these flags have been removed and to reiterate that my group will proudly continue to carry these flags in this House.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: It is referring to Article 10 [of the rules of procedure]. I will switch to German because I only have the German version.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: They are not banners and they are not symbols that disturb the order of plenary, so that rule of the Rules of Procedure cannot be applied to these symbols.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Mr Zanni, I would like to begin by thanking Mr Zanni for his excellent work. There is no discussion of the President's orders here. If you want to oppose the president's order, you can do that, and that will be decided. But for as long as I ask you to heed them.

name: Brian MONTEITH
text: – (Off-mic)

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Another point of order but I will only take it when everyone has followed the order of the President. As long as that is not the case, we will not continue the discussion. (Generalised applause) (Chant from certain quarters ‘Let him speak’) Sorry, colleagues, but it is you who are not letting him speak because you are not following the order of the President. Just do so and we will let him speak. There is no problem. There is another point of order from Ms Strugariu.

name: Ramona STRUGARIU
text: – Madam President, let me point out to my colleagues that, if they read properly the rules of this House they will see that we can’t even have a glass of water on the table, but we can decently put it under the table so, colleagues, you can just take them and put them under the table and they are there with you to represent you. (Loud applause) (Interjection from the floor: ‘My flag is not a glass of water.’)  (Loud applause from certain quarters)

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, the Rules of Procedure contain the words that ‘Members shall not display banners’, so it all hinges on the definition of what is a banner. Is a flag a banner? I’ve just looked up the definition of a banner on Wikipedia, and it says: ‘A banner can be a flag or other piece of cloth bearing a symbol, logo, slogan or other message’. So the President would appear to be within his rights to ask for these flags to be removed. I am not saying it is a wise decision but it is a legal decision.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: I have time. I have a lot of time. Now, the point is not what is a banner and what is not a banner: the point is that if the President of this House comes to a decision, then this decision is to be obeyed as long as it is not taken back. It is as easy as that. Keep calm, keep calm, it is Thursday and everybody wants to go home, I understand that completely. I will now start with the vote.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The next item is the vote.  (For the results and other details of the vote: see Minutes)

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: – Madam President, I would like to denounce very serious events less than twenty-four hours ago in Caracas, where the regime's paramilitary organizations attacked the vehicles where the President of the National Assembly was travelling with stones, sticks and gunfire.  (The president interrupts the speaker).)

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: Sorry, dear colleague, but do you have a point of order or an oral amendment? We’re not reopening the debate.

name: Leopoldo LÓPEZ GIL
text: – I would specifically like to request that the lives of legitimately elected Members in the National Assembly of Venezuela be guaranteed in addition to the Resolution.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: At which point of the resolution do you want to add which words? I am sorry but it is not an oral amendment and we will move on.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: That concludes the vote.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union was an ideal of peace so that war would never again ravage the soil of our continent. It was also an ideal of cooperation between all European peoples. Europe has already experienced 50 years of division and the permanent risk of a return to war. It is in the name of this ideal, unfortunately far away today, that I challenge the Europe's defence project. Defense against whom? Against Russia? Another European country that should be our partner and not our adversary? Defense with whom? With NATO, an obsolete and bellicose organization attached to the tank of American imperialism, making us in solidarity with the reckless actions of Donald Trump? That is not reasonable.  The Europe of defence is the Europe of war. On the contrary, let us return to the path of dialogue by organising a major conference on peace and cooperation in Europe to reduce tensions. Let us address the climate and environmental challenge, rather than add the fires of war to the great global fire.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, this is going to be the last speech I make in this Chamber. It’s difficult to recall the world when I was first elected. There was no Wiki, no WiFi, you had to get your tickets through a travel agent, they would come in physical form and our post arrived in envelopes with stamps on. An awful lot of things have changed, but one thing that hasn’t changed is the direction of this Chamber and the other institutions, despite referendums against closer integration in the Netherlands, in France, in Denmark, in Ireland, in Greece and of course in the United Kingdom, it’s still full speed ahead to closer and closer integration and it was that ultimately that I think made inevitable that Britain would take a different trajectory. So as we leave let me wish the many friends I’ve made here, including the committed believers in a federal Europe, every possible success. You can always rely on our open markets, on our military alliance, on our diplomatic support, but we will now be living under our own laws and for the rest of you, good luck. Bon courage. (Applause)

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I feel that it is after Brexit, after the departure of the United Kingdom, that some of our colleagues and some political forces in this European Parliament have renewed their ambitions to develop a separate autonomous security and defence policy. Ambitions that completely ignore the need for transatlantic ties that ignore the only security umbrella at our disposal, the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation. For my part and for my country, I say that we are not satisfied with this development, that we will always promote transatlantic security and defence ties, and that we will not allow the creation of any autonomous or parallel structures with NATO that would weaken this link.

name: Manuel BOMPARD
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is sick of free trade, austerity and free and undistorted competition. It broke with popular sovereignty when it ratified the Lisbon Treaty, which was rejected in 2005 by the French people. It is in the process of dislocation: Brexit is a clear illustration of this. Therefore, a conference on the future of Europe can only make sense if it seeks to re-establish the link between peoples and European integration. The first step is to acknowledge the faultyness of the Lisbon Treaty, rather than pretending that this sad episode did not exist. The objective must then be to clarify: to revise illegitimate European treaties which engrave in the marble economic policies whose consequences are now massively rejected. Finally, we must commit that the outcome of any conference on the future of the European Union will be subject to the ratification of the peoples of the Member States, wherever possible, by referendum. That is the meaning of the amendments that we have proposed. Unfortunately, this Parliament has chosen to reject them, as if it wanted to continue in its bubble, despite the ever-increasing distrust of the citizens. So let him not count on us to approve his communication operation, which will still cause a great deal of disillusionment.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, I abstained on this motion because as the Director of the Academy of Ideas in the UK, I am a champion of public debate, increased civil society and engagement in politics, and citizens having more chances to discuss their views. This is a virtue in its own terms. However, in this motion for this conference that the EU is organising, citizen engagement seems more about window dressing to save the EU’s reputation as a top-down bureaucracy with a major democratic deficit.  The motion made it clear that this is not about free debate or trusting citizens, it is stage-managed. In the motion it included the phrase that said ‘we need to provide preparatory sessions for well-established civil society groups and other experts to prepare the citizens’, i.e. they don’t trust citizens. Worse, the motion rejected amendments saying that the conference should be an open process with no predetermined goals. That was rejected and voted against, and rejected the conference as a chance for a fundamental debate on the EU.  I’m sorry but this is a wasted opportunity and a PR exercise. I wish you well in this Parliament, but you’ve really got to let the citizens speak freely and trust them and not keep trying to take over.

name: Veronika VRECIONOVÁ
text: – Madam President, the debate on the future of the European Union is not only much needed in the context of Brexit. However, the assignment we voted on is very narrow and misleading. After all, the debate on the future of the EU should not only lead to a further devolution of powers from the Member States to the EU, but should, in particular, aim at reflecting Brexit and the actual functioning of the Union. Existing Union competences should be audited and those not necessary for it should be returned to the nation States. But with this reflection, the proposals do not count. They are counting on further integration and a repetitive game of Pan-European elections, although it has already failed twice. I fear that the result will be a further departure of citizens from the EU and a further increase in extreme forces in Europe, which is why I did not support this proposal.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab One of the founding fathers of the European Community, Robert Schuman, who was recalled very often yesterday, said: "Europe will be either Christian or not at all." And what did we hear yesterday during this debate? Ano we have heard that the most important thing for the future of Europe – although Europe has been confused with the institutions of the European Union here – is the debate on the role of spitzekandidat and that the future of Europe depends on mr Verhofstadt at the head of this conference.  Roger Scruton, a prominent English philosopher and defender of a European civilization based on tradition, who died a few days ago, said: "You have to have a vision of the future and a vision of the goal you are aiming for. It is not good to respond only to the dangers of today by improvising responses. We need to know what our society wants to look like."  I voted against this resolution because the demands that have been made here, not a single sentence, have referred to the future of Europe as a community of values. The foundation of Europe is Christian values derived from the Old and New Testaments, Greek philosophy and Roman law, and you are talking about who will be spitzekandidat.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Voorzitter, een conferentie over de toekomst van Europa, een zoveelste praatbarak geleid door duurbetaalde politici - establishmentpolitici - gaat de democratische crisis in Europa echt niet oplossen. If you want to get closer to European citizens and workers, perhaps we can start by cutting wages: Mrs van der Leyen, President of the European Commission, earns some 32,000 euros a month; Charles Michel, as President of the Council, about as much; a Member of Parliament easily reaches 10,000 euros per month. How do you want to understand, by earning such wages, what are the experiences of workers who cannot reach the end of the month? That's impossible. And while we are at it, let us prevent people who come directly from multinationals from becoming European Commissioners or Ministers in the future: it is equally incomprehensible. At that point, perhaps there will be a beginning of credibility in these institutions.

name: Alexandr VONDRA
text: – Madam President, in two weeks' time, we will be saying goodbye to our British friends, I will see you for the last time in plenary in Brussels, and one would hope that we will somehow learn from this, that we will not push, that we will take our minds off it. Unfortunately, the debate that is being opened here is exactly the opposite. Just keep stoming on the gas to an ever closer European Union is what will divide Europe, nations from each other and the nobility here in this building from normal people in the field. And I, as a man who has cheered that we got rid of communism and became part of Western Europe, I just stare that today my conservative faction is excluded from this debate because our views do not suit you, while the Communists here in this building who want to hug Putin and who want to break up NATO are welcome in this debate.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, colleagues, I strongly voted against parliament's position on the conference on the future of Europe, because this resolution not only does not respond, not only is it not a medicine, it is a recipe for a political disease called far-left liberalism.  The answers in this resolution are not what Europe's sensible future is. Because the future of Europe is not in the imposed dictatorship here of majorities, it is not in the continuing imposition of multicultural society, it is not in the continuing imposition of same-sex marriage, it is not in the continuing imposition of erroneous family models. The future of Europe, as we imagine it, the people who define ourselves as patriots and patriots, is in a strong Europe of strong fatherness, in a Europe based on Christian values, christian traditions, in a Europe that respects national self-consciousness and national self-determination.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I remember that many years ago I was a member of the so-called 'European Union'. Convention on the Future of Europe. I'm afraid we're now moving towards some similar model by bringing this conference to life. And I remember well that the convention, which eventually resulted in a European constitution, which was then renamed the Treaty of Lisbon, was initially dominated by federalists in the European Parliament and on the European political scene, and had only one task – to push deeper integration, to give more power to the European institutions, more powers to take away from nation states. I fear that we are now facing a similar development, it can also be seen from the fact that critical voices, Eurorealist voices, voices that do not want deeper integration, are excluded from this debate in advance and that is something that is simply unacceptable.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: Madam President, Juan Guaid and Nicols Maduro are definitely obsessed with our Chamber. One is adorned with all the virtues. He has just been elected to the seat of his newspaper and our Parliament thinks that is normal. If tomorrow our fellow environmentalists hold a vote in their newspaper, will they be able to boast of being presidents of our assembly? In short, Nicols Maduro concentrates our criticisms and we understand that. Stuck in ideological excesses, he condemned a large part of his population to exile. At the same time, we can see that what is attracting the attention of the international community are Maduro's alliances with his declared adversaries of the United States. But are U.S. sanctions helping the Venezuelan people? Do they not, on the contrary, prove that behind humanitarian displays lies a political will to exercise cultural and economic hegemony over this part of the world? A humanitarian emergency is not resolved through economic sanctions. When is there a broad reflection on this issue of sanctions, embargoes, the extension of these sanctions to families, relatives and tomorrow why not to neighbours? These practices conceal, under the humanitarian question, the exercise of immense political pressure.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – Madam President, I supported this resolution, which criticises the further illegitimate and illegal actions of dictator Maduro. We have talked about him many times in plenary, so unfortunately he is tenacious and has strengthened his power again by illegally changing the President of parliament. We should consider what has been said, which is to tighten sanctions against the representatives of the Maduro regime and whether to take a tougher course of action, because clearly Maduro still has the strength to survive. In addition, our humanitarian aid is needed, which we have talked about many times. The situation in the country is absolutely terrible, there is a humanitarian disaster, and I therefore support us to continue to participate and, on the contrary, to strengthen humanitarian aid to the people of this country, who are not to be responsible for being ruled by such a left-wing dictator.

name: Guido REIL
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I voted in favour of the resolution. For 20 years now, Venezuela has been suffering under this socialist dictatorship, and, as in any other country, socialism has caused poverty and hardship and, above all, lack of freedom. This must finally stop! Venezuela is actually a rich country, Venezuela has the largest oil reserves in the world, and yet 70 percent of all children there suffer from malnutrition, and 3 million Venezuelans have now fled. This must finally stop! This country finally needs freedom and democracy.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: – Madam President, the EU’s continued recognition of Guaidó is even more farcical now, given that on 5 January, with 150 of the 165 Members present, the National Assembly elected Luis Parra as its new President. Parra is from the right-wing opposition party Primero Justicia and was elected with 81 votes. Nor was Guaidó refused access to the National Assembly, as claimed by Josep Borrell. He’s on camera inside the gated area, calmly refusing to enter unless he was allowed to take with him 11 former members of the Assembly. The event with him climbing the railing was staged afterwards.  The Declaration by Josep Borrell, expressing full support to Guaidó as President of the National Assembly is so disappointing and for me it’s a disgrace. The EU leadership is supporting anti-democratic regime change again. It’s crazy. Why don’t we leave the Venezuelan people to themselves? It’s time to stop inflicting suffering on these people and force the Americans to lift the sanctions and let the Venezuelans decide their future.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Madam President, I also voted on this resolution, and I am amazed that I still hear in the plenary of Parliament people who see Maduro differently than as a dictator. He is a dictator, and every dictator I have known throughout history, I have firmly observed that he despises his own people.  So we must give a signal of solidarity with the millions of Venezuelan citizens who are suffering during this period, we must act much more firmly through our diplomacy to sanction this criminal regime that has led and put millions of citizens in incredible situations. So I stand with Venezuela and we must fight for the freedom of this people.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: – Madam President, I am glad that we are dealing with the situation in Venezuela once again in the plenary of the European Parliament. The reality is that, as far as Latin America is concerned, the left of the European Parliament, which prevails here, let us face it, is very happy to shoot into regimes such as Brazil or Colombia, simply those it regards as right-wing, and, on the contrary, very much silent about regimes that we could boldly call left-wing dictatorships, be it Cuba or Nicaragua or, after all, Venezuela. So it is good that we have dealt with this, and it is good that we are dealing with it, and it is good that we are going to deal with this, and I think that unconstitutional actions, human rights violations and the tragic economic situation into which Venezuela has been introduced by the socialist regime is an important thing on our foreign policy agenda.

name: Claire FOX
text: – Madam President, I voted against this motion because Article 7 is being used as a bullying weapon in defiance of the Hungarian and Polish voters. It is they, the Hungarian and Polish voters, and only they who should decide if their governments need punishment. There is a tension in this Parliament, this relentless push by the EU to a federalist system in which all national cultural and political differences need to be eradicated and squashed seems to be incredibly destructive. You say you embrace diversity, but you never embrace diversity of opinion. And you show contempt for national sovereignty, shown, by the way, by the arbitrary diktat that you ban national flags from groups in this place.
