name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question to the Commission on 3D-printed illicit objects by Lucy Nethsingha on behalf of the Committee on Legal Affairs (O-000002/2020 (B9-0002/2020).

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: author. – Madam President, 3D printing is a technology with significant economic potential for European businesses, notably for small, innovative enterprises, and many countries have started to adapt strategies to promote its development. The technology, however, also raises legal and ethical questions. Different studies by the Commission have shown the existence of loopholes in EU legislation regarding the use of 3D printing. Recent tragic events have raised concerns and confirmed the need for action at EU level. On 9 October 2019, two people were killed and two people were injured in Halle, Germany, when an attacker tried to enter the local synagogue during Yom Kippur, the Jewish holiday. The attacker used a 3D—printed weapon, the blueprint of which he uploaded on Twitter. Already in its 2018 report, the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) expressed concerns regarding the manufacturing of weapons, explosives, drugs and other hazardous products in the context of 3D printing, but also regarding the problems relating to civil liability and intellectual property rights. In light of the urgency of this matter, the JURI Committee would like to ask the Commission the following: How do you intend to tackle this problem raised by the use of 3D—printed illicit objects? Do you foresee taking any legislative action based on ongoing and previous studies and evaluations? If so, which EU measures do you foresee to be impacted, and what is the timeline of the actions you plan to undertake? What will you do to ensure a timely response? Finally, what progress has been made regarding the actions the Commission has committed to undertake following the 2018 JURI Committee report?

name: Janez Lenarčič
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I share this Parliament’s view as it was expressed in its 2018 report that the distinguished author of the question mentioned, namely that 3D printing technology may also raise security, and especially cybersecurity, concerns, particularly with regard to the manufacturing of weapons, explosives and drugs, and any other hazardous objects, and that particular care should be taken with regard to production of that kind.  The main problem with three-dimensional printed firearms is not that they are defective and therefore subject to the Product Liability Directive. The actual problem is that these firearms were illegally manufactured and used. According to the Directive on the acquisition and possession of weapons, also known as the Firearms Directive, the manufacturing of weapons is already illicit unless it is authorised by a competent authority of the Member State where the manufacture or assembly takes place. And this applies also to manufacturing through 3D printing and using technical specifications available on the Internet.  Monitoring of the situation is currently taking place in the context of the EU policy cycle for organised and serious international crime. The Operational Action Plan 2020 includes an operational action aiming at raising awareness of the threat of the use of new technologies, such as 3D printers. Europol issued in October last year an intelligence notification for all law enforcement authorities on this subject.  The Commission is preparing a report on the application of the Directive, covering issues notably related to the impacts of new technologies such as three-dimensional printing. This report, which is due by September this year, will assess whether further action with respect to 3D printing is required.

name: Ibán GARCÍA DEL BLANCO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, I believe that all of us who have approached and approached this issue will agree that we are facing a tool, a technological and also democratizing advance which, in some way, represents a great opportunity. 3D printing certainly has many different approaches, but it is clear that it can help us, even from the point of view of saving materials, from the point of view of less contamination. We are talking about the possibility of production, the possibility of producing more and more with, in addition, larger tools and machines with greater capacity in the place where you want to establish the activity avoids transport, for example, as well. A democratization, in the end, as I said, of access to certain things. But it is also true, on the other hand, that it also poses a major challenge with respect to a lot of things. Security is one of them. Reference has been made before to what has to do with the possibility of, without going any further, building weapons. And we have had some examples during these last few months and these last years of the difficulty that still exists of control of certain things, certain planes, certain ways of building that can even be downloaded from the same website, from what is called the deep internet, from the deep web. And also, of course, it poses another set of challenges that, legally, are not yet well solved. And I would like to take this opportunity to ask the Commission to take this into account from the point of view of its own respect for intellectual property. And there are also a lot of examples of how, in some way, there is little control over the use of intellectual production of people or groups who have somehow been working on intellectual productions. And there is not enough protection yet in our legislation. More importantly, the exceptions being raised are too vague and too broad. I would like that, as we have done with so many things and as we have done with the website itself and with the use, with the digital use of one's own access to intellectual and cultural content, we will also do so in this area. Anyway, and I'm done with this. Sorry about the extension. I encourage the Commission, above all, to fill in some legal loopholes and also, in some ways, to coordinate and harmonise some legislation that already exists.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, thank you to the Commission for its answer. Well, allow me to continue in my mother tongue, Dutch. Mr President, 3D printing: it is a technology that has taken off and still has a lot of potential for European companies, both large companies and small and medium-sized enterprises. The possibilities are endless and it has already improved our lives. Think, for example, of printing prosthetics in the medical world, or in construction, where a small house can now be built in 48 hours.  But as with many innovations, this innovation also has a downside when it falls into the wrong hands, as we saw in that terrible event in Halle, Germany, where someone tried to enter the synagogue, killing two people and injuring two people. So while 3D printing does us a lot of good, we can't turn a blind eye to other possibilities and dangerous applications, such as printing weapons, explosives or drugs. We must therefore ask ourselves whether we have settled it well enough, and the answer is no.  The Commission has just indicated that it has taken steps, the Operational Action Plan. The police and prosecution authorities have also been put on the move. But the question is whether this is enough, because if you dive into it, there does indeed appear to be a patchwork of intellectual property rules, but also civil liability and, of course, the Firearms Directive. The Commission itself has already said that the weapons have been printed illegally. Yes, okay, how are we going to prevent that? Because yet this could happen.  So my question is to the Commission: you have already said what actions you have taken, but do we need new legislation and new standards? Because I believe that you really – and everyone here with me – believe that such an incident as in Germany should never happen again.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, Commissioner, honourable one, two, three, four colleagues in the Chamber, before I begin with the substantive issue raised by the honourable Member, I would like to address you, Madam President, and say something I said at the last meeting and the past, and I will continue to say so until measures are taken. The presence of so many people in the chamber on Thursday, on a working day, is an insult to taxpayers and a disappointment to those people there who come to watch the work of Parliament. It must be changed – either there is no meeting on the Thursday after lunch, or the living rooms are paid after the end of the meeting, or paid for half a day. Such a presence and such a debate on an important topic, I say again, is an insult to taxpayers and to the people who look at us here. So measures need to be taken. Please hand this over. Now on the topic: undoubtedly the entry of new technologies into all spheres of our lives poses new challenges. 3D printing is an important technology that leads to extremely valuable achievements in a number of fields such as medicine, construction and research. Just as no one can predict the impact of the steam machine in 1750 or the printing press in 1450, we cannot predict today what the long-term impact of 3D printing will be. It is clear that in addition to the undeniably useful applications of this technology, it will also carry risks. Weapons printing is a niche that is not regulated and needs to be carefully examined. It is irresponsible for people with no moral standing to have access to three-dimensional printed weapons after a few minutes of searching the world wide web. These weapons are untraceable, virtually undetectable, and can be accessed to any criminal, abuser or terrorist. But I would like to draw your attention to something else – the mere fact that there are people who resort to three-dimensional printing to obtain a personal weapon shows the following thing: the laws in a number of Member States of the European Union on the possession of personal weapons are unnecessarily restrictive and prevent conscientious citizens who want to protect themselves and their family. In my country, in Bulgaria, there is a huge problem with domestic crime per carried out by non-socialized marginal groups. For a number of citizens in small settlements who do not have access to police protection, owning a personal weapon is the only way to protect themselves and their family. Let me remind you that the only one who can stop a bad man with a gun is a good man with a gun. Whatever regulations and regulations are adopted on three-dimensionally printed weapons, they must not affect the legally acquired weapon. This hall has talked many times about limiting the possession of hunting weapons, sports weapons, limiting in the sphere, for example, the use of steel ball bearings, replacing them with lead, and others, to put it mildly, insane restrictions that, instead of being for the benefit of citizens, burden them and destroy old, traditional sports such as hunting and sports shooting. Let's take serious steps to liberalize the regime for acquiring not only the personal weapon, but also the sports and collectibles. You know that only the free man is the armed man. (The Speaker agrees to answer a blue card question (Rule 171(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Andrey SLABAKOV
text: a question asked by raising a blue card. – Madam President, I have, in addition to some kind of speech, questions to Mr Dzhambazki. I can't understand how you can even distinguish between a normal and printed weapon. I mean, there can be no difference, and that's my question to Mr. Dzhambazki: whether he thinks there's any difference between the two. The regimes are extremely strange because there is no difference between carrying and owning a weapon. According to my understanding in my home, which should be inviable and no one has the right to enter it, I can hold, if I like, a heavy machine gun. I think that's normal. Maybe I just like heavy machine guns. And I don't understand these strange restrictive laws in which people are forbidden to defend their own lives.  I can give you an example with Bulgaria that in Bulgaria, if someone attacks me with an axe, I have to answer with the same weapon, that is, I probably have to put a suitcase of weapons next to my bed if they come into the house.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by raising a blue card. – Colleague Weakakov, I largely share your opinion. I think that in order not to force people to make 3D-printed weapons, every single citizen who obeys the laws, every single citizen who does not have a conviction, every single citizen who is a taxpayer should be able to acquire opportunities to protect himself and his family without breaking the laws, of course.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: Now I would like to give the floor back to the Commission.  Commissioner Lenarčič, the floor is yours for the final remarks.

name: Janez Lenarčič
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you for this short but very interesting debate. I will take this back and I can assure you that the Commission will look at this matter from all the angles that were mentioned today. But I can already give you some preliminary feedback on each of them.  I will start with intellectual property rights. The Commission recently commissioned a study on the intellectual property rights implications of the development of industrial three—dimensional printing. The purpose of this study is to analyse the intellectual property implications of the development of industrial 3D printing. The Commission will take account of the study’s conclusions and recommendations and will decide on the next steps. Obviously, the fight against counterfeited products, be it through 3D printing or any other production method, is of paramount importance for the Commission. On product liability, this is a matter that is covered by the Product Liability Directive. On this issue, I can tell you that the Commission published its fifth report on the Product Liability Directive and the evaluation of the Directive back in 2018. It also published a staff working document on liability for emerging digital technologies in the same year. In addition, the Commission is working on a guidance document for the implementation of the Directive and this guidance document should be available later this year. Furthermore, the Commission is examining whether it would be useful to amend the Product Liability Directive. Finally, on the illicit arms production angle, the incident that you mentioned in Halle was of course looked at very closely by the German authorities. Among others, the German Bundestag found that no legislative changes are necessary because the current German law explicitly sanctions the unlicensed manufacture of guns and firearms regardless of the method of their production. Nevertheless, the Commission will submit to this Parliament and to the Council a report on the application of the Firearms Directive, including a fitness check of its provisions accompanied, if appropriate, by legislative proposals, notably concerning the impacts of new technologies such as 3D—printing, but also the use of QR code and the use of radio—frequency identification.
